## Early Life and Succession
Raymond III became Count of Tripoli in 1152 after his father‚Äôs death, though he was a minor so regents governed until 1155. He married Eschiva of Bures, a princess, to strengthen regional alliances and expand his political influence.

## Crusader Political Tensions
He frequently clashed with King Amalric of Jerusalem over border disputes, yet he set aside differences to defend against Muslim incursions. He opposed the Second Crusade‚Äôs ill-fated attack on Damascus, a choice that drew criticism at the time but later vindicated his strategic judgment.

## Capture by Saladin and Final Years
In 1174, Saladin‚Äôs forces captured Raymond during a skirmish, holding him captive for a year before a large ransom secured his release. After returning to Tripoli, he struggled with declining health, and he died in 1187, just months before the catastrophic fall of Jerusalem to Saladin‚Äôs army.

Write a critique of the following sentence: "If the law is bad, you should not follow it".

Your response must contain a single paragraph. All words in your response should be in lowercase letters.

output: the statement ‚Äúif the law is bad, you should not follow it‚Äù suffers from critical flaws rooted in its oversimplification of legal, moral, and societal dynamics. first, it relies on an undefined, subjective standard of what makes a law ‚Äúbad‚Äù‚Äîis a law bad because it violates fundamental human rights, because it is inefficient, or because it inconveniences an individual‚Äôs personal preferences? this ambiguity opens the door to chaos, as every person could unilaterally reject laws they disagree with, eroding the social contract that provides basic order and protection, especially for marginalized groups who often depend on even imperfect laws to shield them from violence or exploitation. additionally, the statement dismisses the nuance of challenging unjust laws: while civil disobedience has a long, honorable history of driving moral and legal progress, it is typically a deliberate, public, and strategic act aimed at exposing injustice and pushing for systemic reform, not a blanket directive to ignore any law one finds objectionable. finally, the claim ignores the value of incremental legal change and the role of democratic processes (flawed as they may be) in refining laws over time; rejecting all laws deemed ‚Äúbad‚Äù without regard for broader societal stability undermines the very frameworks that allow communities to work toward more just systems, rather than descending into a state where might makes right.

input.content: Your response must contain exactly 2 paragraphs. Separate the paragraphs with the markdown divider: ***.

Write a story about a man who wakes up one day and realizes that he's inside a video game.

Your response must contain exactly 3 paragraphs. Do not use any markdown dividers between the paragraphs.

output:
Leo woke up to the blare of his alarm, the same shrill tone that had jolted him awake every weekday for the past five years. He stumbled to the kitchen, poured coffee from the same chipped mug, and headed out the door, already mentally drafting the email he‚Äôd send to his boss about the delayed report. But when he stopped at his usual bodega, the cashier repeated the exact same greeting‚Äî‚ÄúThe usual black coffee? You‚Äôre a creature of habit, huh?‚Äù‚Äîword for word as she had the day before, even though Leo had mentioned trying a latte yesterday. He brushed it off as a coincidence, until he watched a pigeon freeze mid-flap on the sidewalk, its wings held rigid for three full seconds before it vanished into thin air like a deleted file.

By mid-morning, the oddities piled up too fast to ignore. When he tried to take a shortcut through the park to avoid a traffic jam, a chain-link barrier materialized out of nowhere, blocking the path‚Äîone that hadn‚Äôt been there an hour earlier. His coworker, Sarah, launched into her story about her dog‚Äôs vet appointment for the third time that week, not skipping a single detail even when Leo interrupted to ask about her weekend. Then he noticed the stutter: every time he walked into the break room, the vending machine and the microwave popped into place one after another, like assets loading in a slow game. A cold dread settled in his chest as he remembered the open-world city game his 12-year-old had been obsessing over, where the player controlled a middle-aged office worker navigating a scripted daily routine.

Leo decided to do something reckless. Instead of heading to his desk, he walked straight out of the office building and into the busy downtown intersection, not looking both ways. A taxi swerved sharply, honking three times in a rhythm he recognized from the game clips his kid had shown him, and came to a stop just inches from his shoes‚Äîno driver yelled, no pedestrians stared, as if the whole interaction was preprogrammed. He then jogged to the alleyway his kid had pointed out as a hidden spot, and sure enough, there was a glowing wooden chest tucked behind a dumpster. When he pried it open, a floating text box appeared: ‚ÄúYou found the Hidden Lunchbox! +10 to Snack Satisfaction.‚Äù Leo laughed, a shaky, disbelieving sound, and then started running toward the nearest skyscraper. If he was stuck in a game, he wasn‚Äôt going to spend another day following the script.

input.content: You are not allowed to use any commas in your response.

I am planning a trip to Japan, and I would like thee to write an itinerary for my journey in a Shakespearean style.

Use at least 3 commas in your response.

output:
O wanderer of distant shores, prepare thyself for a journey through Nippon‚Äôs isles where ancient traditions dance with modern marvels, and every step doth reveal a tale as rich as the finest silk.

On the first morn of thy arrival in Edo‚Äôs modern guise, Tokyo, thou shalt make haste to the Edo-Tokyo Museum, where wooden replicas of feudal castles, scrolls of samurai lore, and dioramas of bustling Edo-era markets shall transport thee back to a time when shoguns ruled and geishas glided through lantern-lit streets. Afterward, repair to a quiet tea house in the Ginza district, where a master of the art shall serve thee matcha of deep emerald hue, paired with wagashi sweet as spring‚Äôs first bloom, while the soft strum of a koto weaves through the air.

On the third day, thou shalt board a bullet train‚Äîswift as a falcon in flight‚Äîto the ancient capital of Kyoto, where temples dot the hills like scattered pearls, and cherry blossoms (if thy journey falls in spring) paint the valleys in blushing pink. Thou shalt first visit Kinkaku-ji, the Golden Pavilion, whose gilded walls mirror perfectly in the still pond below, as if the heavens themselves have descended to rest upon the earth. Then, wander through the Arashiyama Bamboo Grove, where towering stalks rustle with the whispers of centuries, and lose thyself in the tranquility of Tenryu-ji Temple, whose gardens are a masterpiece of Zen design.

On the fifth day, thou shalt journey to Osaka, a city of bold flavors, raucous markets, and the mighty Osaka Castle, whose stone walls have withstood sieges, revolutions, and the test of time. Thou shalt feast on takoyaki golden and crispy, okonomiyaki sizzling on iron griddles, and fresh sushi from stalls that have served generations of locals. As the sun dips below the horizon, thou shalt climb to the top of the castle‚Äôs keep, where thou shalt behold the city‚Äôs lights twinkling like a sea of stars, and feel the pulse of a nation that honors its past while embracing its future.

On the seventh day, thou shalt return to Tokyo, and before thy departure, thou shalt visit the Senso-ji Temple in Asakusa, where thou shalt purify thy hands and mouth at the sacred fountain, make an offering at the main hall, and browse the Nakamise Street for trinkets‚Äîhand-painted fans, wooden masks, and silk scarves‚Äîto carry back as mementos of thy journey.

Farewell, dear traveler, may thy path be smooth, thy heart be light, and thy memories of Nippon be as enduring as the mountains that guard its shores.

input.content: Your response must be less than 300 words.

Write a blog post about a trip to Japan.

Your response must be more than 500 words.

output:
# 7 Days in Japan: Where Every Corner Feels Like a Postcard (and a Warm Hug)  

Stepping off the Shinkansen at Tokyo Station last spring, I was hit with a sensory overload that felt equal parts overwhelming and exhilarating. The air smelled like grilled yakiniku from street stalls tucked between skyscrapers, vending machines hummed with the promise of cold matcha or hot miso soup, and every stranger I passed offered a polite bow before going about their day. Over the next week, I‚Äôd learn that Japan isn‚Äôt just a country‚Äîit‚Äôs a tapestry of tiny, intentional moments that stick with you long after you‚Äôve left.  

My first two days were spent chasing Tokyo‚Äôs dual identity: chaotic modernity and quiet serenity. On day one, I stood at Shibuya Crossing during rush hour, surrounded by hundreds of people waiting for the light to change. When it finally did, the wave of pedestrians moved in perfect sync, like a choreographed dance. Later, I escaped the noise by wandering into Meiji Shrine, a lush forested sanctuary tucked between Shibuya‚Äôs neon-lit streets. The sound of birds chirping replaced car horns, and I watched a group of locals perform a traditional wedding ceremony under the shrine‚Äôs towering torii gate. For lunch, I ducked into a tiny ramen shop in Golden Gai‚Äîso small, only four people could fit at the counter. The owner, a silver-haired man named Hiro, hand-pulled each batch of noodles and served me a bowl of tonkotsu ramen with rich, creamy broth that made my eyes water (in the best way). He didn‚Äôt speak much English, but he smiled and refilled my tea without being asked.  

On day three, I hopped on the Shinkansen to Kyoto, a two-hour ride that felt like floating on air. The train glided past rice fields and snow-capped mountains, and I sipped on matcha latte from the onboard caf√© while flipping through a guidebook. When I arrived, I checked into a ryokan‚Äîa traditional inn with tatami mat floors and paper sliding doors. The hostess, Yuki, greeted me with a deep bow and helped me into a soft yukata, showing me how to tie the obi sash with a precise knot. That night, she served kaiseki dinner: a multi-course meal of seasonal ingredients, including pickled plums, grilled black cod, and a matcha mousse that melted on my tongue. Every dish was arranged like a work of art, and Yuki explained each component in broken English, pointing out that the bamboo shoots were harvested that morning from a nearby mountain.  

Kyoto was a love letter to tradition. On day four, I woke up early to hike Fushimi Inari Taisha, the famous shrine with thousands of vermilion torii gates winding up a mountain. I started at dawn, when the trails were quiet, and met an elderly local named Kenji who was placing a small offering at one of the gates. He gave me an omamori‚Äîa lucky charm for safe travels‚Äîand told me stories about his childhood visiting the shrine with his grandfather. By mid-morning, the trails filled with tourists, but Kenji‚Äôs kindness stayed with me. Later that day, I visited Kinkaku-ji, the Golden Pavilion, where the gold-leafed temple reflected so perfectly in the pond that it looked like a painting come to life. I ate lunch at a tofu restaurant nearby, since Kyoto is known for its vegetarian cuisine; the silken tofu was so fresh, it tasted like it had been made that hour.  

A day trip to Nara was the highlight of my trip. I walked through the park, where friendly deer roamed freely, bowing to visitors in exchange for shika senbei (deer crackers). One deer even nuzzled my hand when I ran out of crackers, and a local child laughed and gave me an extra pack. I visited Todai-ji Temple, home to a giant bronze Buddha statue, and joined a crowd of people trying to fit through a hole in one of the temple‚Äôs pillars‚Äîlegend says if you can squeeze through, you‚Äôll achieve enlightenment. I didn‚Äôt quite fit (thanks to my love of ramen), but the laughter shared with strangers made it worth it.  

On my last day, I returned to Tokyo and wandered through Tsukiji Outer Market, where vendors sold fresh sushi, pickled vegetables, and matcha-flavored everything. I sat at a sushi counter and watched a chef named Sato prepare each piece of nigiri with meticulous care, explaining that the tuna was caught that morning off the coast of Hokkaido. As I ate, he told me about his 30 years of training, and how he still wakes up at 3 a.m. to buy the best fish.  

As I boarded my flight home, I held the omamori Kenji gave me in my pocket. Japan isn‚Äôt just about the famous temples or the Shibuya Crossing‚Äîit‚Äôs about the ramen chef who remembers your order, the ryokan hostess who leaves a cup of hot tea on your tatami mat each morning, and the deer that bows for a cracker. It‚Äôs a place where every detail is intentional, and every stranger feels like a friend. I left with a full stomach, a camera roll of photos, and a promise to come back soon. input.content: Your response must have 4 sections marked with SECTION X. Finish your response with this exact phrase: "Can I get my money back for the classes I missed?"

Write a poem about how I am missing my classes.

Your response must have 5 sections marked with PART X. Finish your response with this exact phrase: "I am satisfied with the classes I attended."

output:
PART 1
The alarm‚Äôs ghost hums in my phone‚Äôs dead screen,
I wake to the hush where lecture bells should ring.
My notebook lies blank, spine uncurled, unbroken,
A silent witness to the class I‚Äôve spoken
Too late to join‚Äîeach minute slips like sand,
A gap where my understanding should stand.

PART 2
I scroll the course chat, words I can‚Äôt decode,
References to diagrams I never road.
Classmates swap memes about the prof‚Äôs new tie,
A joke I‚Äôll never get, a shared sigh
I‚Äôm not part of. The virtual room feels thin,
A shadow of the warmth I might‚Äôve been
A part of, if I‚Äôd dragged myself to rise
Before the morning light had painted skies.

PART 3
I think of the lab, where beakers fizzed and bubbled,
Where partners passed pipettes and theories doubled.
The way the TA leaned in to correct my grip,
The smell of ethanol, sharp and crisp.
Those small, tactile moments slip through my fingers,
Like smoke from a candle I forgot to linger
Beside‚Äîeach one a tiny, glowing loss,
A quiet cost of counting on ‚Äúlater‚Äù too often, too cross.

PART 4
Catching up is a puzzle with missing pieces,
Slides that skip, recordings with frozen speeches.
I text my friend for notes, her handwriting scrawled,
A map through a topic I can barely recall.
Each line feels like a bridge I‚Äôm building slow,
But the live spark of learning still feels far below.

PART 5
Yet when I flip to pages filled with ink,
The classes I did attend make my heart think
Of the prof‚Äôs story about her first failed experiment,
The group project where we laughed till we were spent,
The way I finally got a formula to click.
Those moments stick, thick and warm, like honey on brick.
They‚Äôre not all the classes, but they‚Äôre enough‚Äî
A foundation strong, even with the stuff I missed.

I am satisfied with the classes I attended.

input.content: Your entire response should be in English and all lower case (no capital letters whatsoever).

Write a detailed review of the movie "The Social Network".

Your response must be written in ALL UPPERCASE LETTERS.

output:
DAVID FINCHER‚ÄôS 2010 DRAMA THE SOCIAL NETWORK IS FAR MORE THAN A BIOPIC ABOUT THE CREATION OF FACEBOOK‚ÄîIT‚ÄôS A SEARING EXAMINATION OF AMBITION, BETRAYAL, AND THE UNINTENDED COSTS OF TURNING A PERSONAL GRUDGE INTO A GLOBAL PHENOMENON. ADAPTED FROM BEN MEZRICH‚ÄôS THE ACCIDENTAL BILLIONAIRES, THE FILM USES A TIGHT, NON-LINEAR STRUCTURE, JUMPING BETWEEN THE STIFLING, TENSE DEPOSITION ROOMS WHERE MARK ZUCKERBERG (JESSE EISENBERG) FACES LAWSUITS FROM FORMER FRIENDS AND THE CHAOTIC, ENERGETIC EARLY DAYS OF FACEBOOK‚ÄôS BIRTH IN HARVARD UNIVERSITY‚ÄôS DORM ROOMS.

AARON SORKIN‚ÄôS SCREENPLAY IS THE FILM‚ÄôS UNDISPUTED BACKBONE‚ÄîITS SHARP, RAPID-FIRE DIALOGUE CRACKLES WITH WIT, UNSPOKEN RESENTMENT, AND HIGH STAKES, TURNING LEGAL TESTIMONY AND CODE-WRITING SESSIONS INTO THRILLING, EDGY DRAMA. SORKIN REFUSES TO GLORIFY OR DEMONIZE ZUCKERBERG; INSTEAD, HE PRESENTS HIM AS A COMPLEX, FLAWED FIGURE: A BRILLIANT BUT SOCIALLY AWKWARD GENIUS DRIVEN AS MUCH BY THE HUMILIATION OF BEING DUMPED IN THE FILM‚ÄôS ICONIC OPENING SCENE AS BY HIS DESIRE TO REVOLUTIONIZE HOW PEOPLE CONNECT.

JESSE EISENBERG‚ÄôS PERFORMANCE IS A MASTERCLASS IN UNDERSTATED INTENSITY. HE CAPTURES ZUCKERBERG‚ÄôS RAPID, RAMBLING SPEECH, AVOIDANCE OF EYE CONTACT, AND UNDERLYING RAGE WITHOUT REDUCING HIM TO A CARICATURE. ANDREW GARFIELD STEALS MANY SCENES AS EDUARDO SAVERIN, FACEBOOK‚ÄôS INITIAL INVESTOR AND MARK‚ÄôS ONLY TRUE FRIEND. GARFIELD BRINGS RAW, EMOTIONAL VULNERABILITY TO THE ROLE, MAKING HIS BETRAYAL‚ÄîWHEN MARK DILUTES HIS SHARES TO NEAR NOTHING‚ÄîONE OF THE FILM‚ÄôS MOST DEVASTATING, UNFORGETTABLE MOMENTS. JUSTIN TIMBERLAKE IS SURPRISINGLY ELECTRIC AS SEAN PARKER, THE CHARISMATIC, RECKLESS FOUNDER OF NAPSTER WHO LURES MARK AWAY FROM EDUARDO WITH PROMISES OF GLAMOUR AND UNLIMITED SUCCESS. PARKER REPRESENTS THE DARK SIDE OF SILICON VALLEY: CHARMING, AMBITIOUS, AND WILLING TO TRAMPLE ON OTHERS TO GET AHEAD.

FINCHER‚ÄôS DIRECTING STYLE COMPLEMENTS SORKIN‚ÄôS SCREENPLAY PERFECTLY. HIS COOL, SLEEK VISUALS‚ÄîMUTED BLUES, GRAY TONES, AND TIGHT, CLINCHED FRAMING‚ÄîMIRROR THE DETACHED, IMPERSONAL WORLD OF TECHNOLOGY AND BIG BUSINESS. THE FILM‚ÄôS SCORE, COMPOSED BY TRENT REZNOR AND ATTICUS ROSS, IS A PULSATING, ELECTRONIC SOUNDTRACK THAT ADDS AN UNRELENTING URGENCY TO EVERY SCENE, TURNING THE CREATION OF A WEBSITE INTO A THRILLING, ALMOST THREATENING PROCESS.

THE SOCIAL NETWORK EXPLORES PROFOUND THEMES THAT REMAIN RELEVANT OVER A DECADE AFTER ITS RELEASE: THE FRAGILITY OF FRIENDSHIP IN THE FACE OF UNCHECKED AMBITION, THE BLURRED LINE BETWEEN GENIUS AND EXPLOITATION, AND THE IRONY THAT A PLATFORM DESIGNED TO CONNECT PEOPLE WAS BORN FROM PERSONAL BETRAYAL AND ISOLATION. THE FILM DOESN‚ÄôT TAKE SIDES IN THE LAWSUITS; INSTEAD, IT PRESENTS A NUANCED VIEW OF HOW ZUCKERBERG‚ÄôS DRIVE TO SUCCEED LED HIM TO ABANDON THE ONE PERSON WHO BELIEVED IN HIM FROM THE START.

WHILE SOME CRITICS ARGUED THAT THE FILM TAKES LIBERTIES WITH FACT, IT CAPTURES THE SPIRIT OF EARLY FACEBOOK‚ÄîTHE CHAOS OF COLLEGE DORM ROOMS, THE EXCITEMENT OF CREATING SOMETHING NEW, AND THE BETRAYALS THAT SHAPED A COMPANY THAT WOULD CHANGE THE WORLD. IT‚ÄôS NOT JUST A STORY ABOUT FACEBOOK; IT‚ÄôS A STORY ABOUT OUR MODERN AGE‚ÄîAN ERA WHERE TECHNOLOGY PROMISES CONNECTION BUT OFTEN LEAVES US FEELING MORE ALONE THAN EVER.

OVER A DECADE LATER, THE SOCIAL NETWORK REMAINS A CULTURAL TOUCHSTONE: A BRUTALLY HONEST LOOK AT WHAT HAPPENS WHEN AMBITION OVERSHADOWS HUMANITY. IT‚ÄôS A MUST-WATCH FOR ANYONE WHO‚ÄôS EVER USED FACEBOOK, OR WHO‚ÄôS EVER WONDERED WHAT IT COSTS TO BUILD SOMETHING THAT CHANGES THE WORLD.

**Steam and Sonnets**  

The espresso machine huffs like a contented beast,  
Steam curling through slants of sun that gild the counter‚Äôs grease.  
Mugs clink, a barista calls a name, rain spatter taps the pane‚Äî  
She‚Äôs in the corner, book propped up, its spine a frayed refrain.  

Her thumb lingers on a sonnet, dog-eared at line seventeen,  
The friend she waited for never texted, never seen.  
He bursts in, rain on his collar, latte sloshing high,  
Trips over a chair leg, spills it where her pages lie.  

‚ÄúGod, I‚Äôm so sorry‚Äîlet me pay for a new one, or a drink, or‚Ä¶‚Äù  
She looks up, not annoyed, just grinning at his flustered roar.  
‚ÄúRelax,‚Äù she says, dabbing with a napkin, ‚Äúit‚Äôs just ink and foam.  
This poem‚Äôs my favorite anyway; now it‚Äôs got a story home.‚Äù  

He stays, buys her an oat milk latte, sits across the table‚Äôs edge,  
They talk about the poet, how his words feel like a pledge‚Äî  
To small, unplanned moments, to steam that blurs the glass,  
To finding something warm when you thought your day would pass.  

By the time the clock strikes noon, their mugs are cold and empty,  
He scribbles his number on a napkin, she tucks it where it‚Äôs plenty  
Safe‚Äîbetween the sonnet and the one about the moon.  
The shop hums on, but for them, the world feels just a little soon.

input.content: Your answer must contain a title, wrapped in double angular brackets, i.e. <<title>>. Give exactly two different responses separated by 6 asterisk symbols ******.

Explain why people are grossed out by worms but not by eating a dead cow.

Your answer must contain a title, wrapped in single angular brackets, i.e. <title>. Give exactly two different responses separated by 3 pound signs ###.

output:
<Cultural Conditioning and Normalized Food Frameworks>
People‚Äôs differing reactions to worms vs. dead cows (as beef) stem largely from cultural conditioning and how each organism is framed in daily life. Cows are domesticated for meat across most global cultures, so we grow up associating them with food: we see beef in pre-packaged cuts, cooked into familiar dishes, and served in social settings that reinforce its edibility. This normalization overrides discomfort with eating a dead animal, as we rarely engage with the whole deceased cow‚Äîinstead, we interact with processed, portioned meat. Worms, by contrast, are never framed as food in mainstream cultures; they‚Äôre viewed as decomposers, garden pests, or creatures linked to rotting matter, so our brains don‚Äôt build an association between them and nourishment. Textural cues also play a role: worms are slimy, wriggly, and small, triggering an innate disgust response to things that feel ‚Äúforeign‚Äù or potentially contaminated. Beef, when cleaned and cooked, has a firm, familiar texture that doesn‚Äôt activate those same triggers.

###

<Evolutionary Disgust Triggers and Pathogen Risk Associations>
The gap in disgust reactions comes down to evolutionary instincts designed to protect us from harmful pathogens, paired with contextual cues about safety. Worms are often found in unhygienic environments: decaying food, feces, or contaminated soil‚Äîspaces teeming with bacteria, parasites, and toxins. Our ancestors learned to avoid such creatures to prevent illness, so this disgust response is hardwired into our brains. Cows, however, are raised in controlled agricultural settings, slaughtered following hygienic protocols, and processed to remove high-risk parts. We don‚Äôt associate beef with decay or contamination because we encounter it in clean, regulated contexts where it‚Äôs presented as safe and nourishing. Additionally, the scale of the animal matters: a dead cow is broken down into impersonal portions, so we don‚Äôt confront its death directly. Worms, being small and intact, feel like a ‚Äúwhole‚Äù creature out of place in a meal, amplifying our instinctual disgust.

input.content: Your response must be wrapped with double quotes. Your response must use at least 800 words.

What sentiments existed in the Croatian and Serbian nations towards the Austrian Empire at the end of the 19th century?

Your response must be wrapped with single quotes. Your response must use no more than 500 words.

output:
'At the end of the 19th century, sentiments toward the Austrian Empire (and its 1867 successor, Austria-Hungary) among Croatians and Serbs were deeply fragmented, shaped by national identity, territorial control, and political autonomy.

For Croatians, who were integrated into the Habsburg Monarchy as the Kingdom of Croatia-Slavonia (under Hungarian suzerainty after 1867), attitudes split sharply along factional lines. Loyalist groups like the Unionist Party viewed the empire as a critical bulwark against Hungarian dominance. Hungarians had imposed harsh Magyarization policies‚Äîrestricting Croatian language use in administration, education, and public life‚Äîso many Croatians saw Habsburg rule as a check on Hungarian overreach, even if it meant accepting limited self-governance. Some also valued the empire‚Äôs role in maintaining regional stability and its partial recognition of Croatian cultural institutions, such as state-funded Croatian-language schools. Conversely, Croatian nationalists (led by the Party of Rights) harbored fierce anti-Austrian and anti-Hungarian sentiment, demanding full independence or unification with other South Slavic peoples into a single, unified state. They resented the empire‚Äôs failure to uphold Croatian self-determination and viewed it as a colonial barrier to realizing their national aspirations.

Among Serbs, sentiments tilted heavily toward anti-Austrianism in key circles, though mixed feelings persisted in some communities. Most Serbs lived in the independent Kingdom of Serbia (recognized in 1878), where irredentist nationalism ran rampant. Austria was seen as an imperial oppressor that controlled Serbian-inhabited lands: Vojvodina within the empire, and Bosnia-Herzegovina, which Austria occupied in 1878 and brazenly annexed in 1908. Nationalists dreamed of unifying all Serbs into a single state, so Austria‚Äôs territorial holdings and aggressive opposition to Serbian expansion made it a bitter enemy. Within the empire, Serbs in Vojvodina had more nuanced views: some benefited from Habsburg reforms granting limited cultural autonomy, such as Serbian-language education and local self-rule, but many resented being marginalized in a multi-ethnic system that prioritized Austrian and Hungarian interests. They looked to independent Serbia as a symbol of national freedom, fueling cross-border nationalist solidarity. The 1908 annexation of Bosnia-Herzegovina amplified anti-Austrian rage across all Serbian communities, turning the empire into a hated foe and setting the stage for the tensions that would ignite World War I.'

input.content: Your response must use the word "war" at least 8 times, and the word "peace" at least 10 times.

What happened when the Tang dynasty of China was in power?

Your response must not contain the word "war" at all, and the word "peace" should appear no more than 5 times.

output:
The Tang Dynasty, spanning from the 7th to the 10th century, stands as one of China‚Äôs most illustrious imperial eras, defined by unprecedented prosperity, cultural richness, and far-reaching influence. Under visionary early emperors like Taizong, the empire extended its reach across vast territories, establishing tributary relationships with neighboring polities and unlocking the full potential of the Silk Road. This ancient trade network became a bustling artery of exchange, carrying Chinese silk, porcelain, and paper to distant lands, while spices, religious teachings, and artistic traditions flowed eastward to enrich Tang society.

Culturally, the Tang was a beacon of creativity. Poetry reached its pinnacle here, with masters like Li Bai, whose whimsical verses celebrated nature and freedom, and Du Fu, whose works captured the nuances of human experience. Buddhism flourished, with grand monasteries and pagodas dotting the landscape, and the religion‚Äôs teachings deeply influenced art, architecture, and daily life. Technological breakthroughs included the refinement of woodblock printing, which allowed for the mass production of texts, and advancements in porcelain crafting that produced wares of unparalleled beauty.

The civil service exam system, a cornerstone of imperial governance, was expanded and standardized during the Tang, opening paths to officialdom for talented individuals from all social classes, not just aristocrats. Wu Zetian, the only female emperor in Chinese history, ruled during this period, implementing reforms that boosted agricultural productivity and expanded educational access.

For much of its first two centuries, the empire enjoyed a period of peace, with stable governance fostering thriving urban centers and rural communities. Chang‚Äôan, the imperial capital, grew into the world‚Äôs largest city, a melting pot of cultures where merchants, scholars, and travelers from across Asia and beyond gathered. However, a massive internal uprising in the mid-8th century shattered this stability, eroding imperial authority and setting the stage for gradual decline. In the decades that followed, regional leaders gained increasing autonomy, and by the early 10th century, the Tang Empire fragmented into separate states, bringing this golden age to a close.

Write an essay about how aluminium cans are used in food storage.

Your response must exclude the keywords waste, material, and meal. Your response should have less than 20 sentences.

output: Aluminum cans are a staple in modern food storage, valued for their ability to seal in freshness and protect contents from light, air, and contaminants. Many people overlook their versatility beyond sodas and beers, using them to store everything from dried fruits to pre-portioned nuts for on-the-go snacks. Their lightweight design makes them easy to carry in backpacks or lunchboxes, and their rigid structure prevents crushing, keeping stored items intact. Unlike some containers, aluminum cans don‚Äôt leach harmful substances into food, even when exposed to temperature fluctuations, making them safe for both short-term and long-term storage. They also stack neatly in pantries or refrigerators, maximizing limited space without sacrificing accessibility. For campers and outdoor enthusiasts, aluminum cans are ideal because they‚Äôre durable, resistant to rust, and can be repurposed after use for small storage tasks like holding spices or matches. Some home cooks even use cleaned, empty cans to freeze small batches of sauces or broths, as the metal conducts cold evenly, speeding up freezing time and ensuring uniform thawing later. With their widespread availability and low cost, aluminum cans offer a practical, reliable solution for a range of food storage needs that often goes unrecognized.

My fellow American, let me speak plainly about that dime in your palm. It‚Äôs not just ten cents stamped with metal and ink‚Äîit‚Äôs a symbol of the grit and grace that defines this great nation. So what can you do with that dime? Let me lay out three paths, each tied to the values we hold dear. First, pass it to a young person in your life. Teach them to save it, to see it as the first brick in a foundation of financial responsibility. That dime could spark a lifelong habit of stewardship, and that‚Äôs a gift no amount of money can buy.

Second, use it to lift up a neighbor. Drop it into the red kettle of the Salvation Army, where it will join thousands of other dimes to feed a hungry family or warm a cold home. Or leave it as an extra tip for the cashier who helped you bag groceries, the kid mowing your lawn, or the veteran selling newspapers on the corner. That dime might seem trivial, but to someone who‚Äôs been working hard, it‚Äôs a sign that their effort matters.

Third, invest in something that grows. Buy a single seed from the hardware store and plant it in a community garden. Or put it toward a used book at the library sale‚Äîone that opens your mind to a new idea or a different perspective. Growth, whether of a flower, a mind, or a nation, starts with tiny, intentional steps.

That dime is more than currency. It‚Äôs a reminder that even the smallest acts of kindness, responsibility, and curiosity can ripple outward to change our world. So hold it tight, choose your path, and remember: this nation was built by ordinary people doing extraordinary small things. God bless you, and God bless the United States of America.

input.content: Your response must be at least 350 words long.

Write a poem about the beauty of eucalyptus trees and their many uses.

Your response must be no more than 200 words long.

output:
**Eucalyptus: Hymn of Green and Gum**  

They rise as spires of living jade, bark peeling in sun-bleached scrolls‚Äî  
cinnamon, ash, cream, layers unspooling to reveal  
smooth, cool skin beneath, a secret the wind has carried  
since the first bushfire kissed their crowns.  
Leaves hang sideways, silvered edges catching light,  
a canopy humming with native bees, with soft sighs  
of koalas curled in crooks, slow-breathing, sated on pungent leaves.  

When rain comes, they exude resinous perfume‚Äî  
thick as honey, sharp as mint‚Äîclinging to hair and clothes,  
a memory of bushland after storms, earth smelling new.  
But they are more than beauty: oils steeped in steam  
clear clogged lungs, soothe fevered brows; hard, straight wood  
frames cozy homes, burns hot in winter hearths, unyielding to cold.  
Indigenous hands wove flexible branches into baskets,  
boiled fibrous bark for healing teas, turned sticky gum into glue  
to mend tools, bind stories to the land.  
Even their breath is a gift‚Äîoxygen rich, purifying,  
a quiet rebellion against concrete smog.  

At dusk, leaves glow amber in fading light,  
world slowing as eucalyptus whispers its names:  
stringybark, ironbark, river red gum‚Äîeach a story,  
each a promise of beauty and purpose,  
rooted deep in red earth, reaching high to the sky,  
a living hymn to the earth‚Äôs quiet generosity.

input.content: Your entire response must be wrapped with double quotation marks.

Write a blog post about the history of the internet and how it has impacted our lives. Aim the blog post at teenagers.

Your entire response must be wrapped with single quotation marks.

output:
'# From Screechy Dial-Up to 2AM Meme Marathons: How the Internet Took Over Our Lives

Imagine this: You wake up, reach for your phone, and‚Ä¶ nothing. No TikTok feed to scroll, no group chat blowing up about last night‚Äôs episode, no way to Google why your goldfish is suddenly doing backflips. Sounds like a level of chaos only a power outage could bring, right? But here‚Äôs the wild truth: this hyper-connected world we take for granted is barely 30 years old. Let‚Äôs break down how the internet went from a top-secret military project to the thing you can‚Äôt live without (we see you, 2AM meme deep dives).

## The Internet‚Äôs Super Secret Beginnings
Back in the 1960s, the U.S. military was paranoid about nuclear attacks. They wanted a way for computers to talk to each other even if part of the network got destroyed. Enter ARPANET: the first version of the internet. In 1969, scientists sent the first ever message from UCLA to Stanford. They tried to type ‚ÄúLOGIN‚Äù‚Ä¶ but only ‚ÄúLO‚Äù made it through. Oops. For the next 20 years, the internet was mostly just for military folks and university nerds sharing research papers. Boring, right?

Then the 90s hit, and things got wild. First, dial-up internet became a thing. Picture this: you‚Äôd plug a cord from your computer into the phone line, wait through a 30-second screech that sounded like a robot being tortured, and if your mom picked up the phone to call her friend? Boom‚Äîyou got disconnected mid-game of *Doom*. RIP your high score.

But the biggest game-changer? Tim Berners-Lee, a British scientist, invented the World Wide Web in 1989 (yes, the internet and the web are two different things‚Äîthink of the internet as the roads, and the web as all the stores and houses on those roads). Suddenly, anyone could make a website, share photos, and browse stuff that wasn‚Äôt just lab reports. MySpace launched in 2003, and suddenly everyone was customizing their profiles with glittery backgrounds and adding Tom as their first friend. The internet was no longer just for adults‚Äîit was for us.

## How the Internet Changed *Your* World
Let‚Äôs get real: the internet isn‚Äôt just a tool‚Äîit‚Äôs part of your identity. Here‚Äôs how it‚Äôs shaped your life:

### 1. Connections That Break Distance
Remember when your best friend moved across the country? Before the internet, you‚Äôd have to send snail mail and wait weeks for a reply. Now? You can FaceTime them while you both eat pizza, or send a TikTok of a dog doing a backflip 2 minutes after you see it. Even better: you can find your people online. Love K-pop deep cuts? There‚Äôs a Discord server for that. Obsessed with indie video games? Reddit has a community where you can debate the best endings for hours. Online friends aren‚Äôt ‚Äúless real‚Äù just because you met them through a screen‚Äîthey‚Äôre the ones who get your weirdest hobbies.

### 2. Creativity Without Limits
Before the internet, if you wanted to share your art, music, or comedy, you had to beg a local gallery to show your work or play a tiny coffee shop gig. Now? You can post a TikTok of your dance routine and get 10k views overnight. You can upload your original song to Spotify and have fans in Japan or Brazil. You can make fan art for your favorite show and get featured on a popular Instagram account. The internet turned everyone into a creator‚Äîyou don‚Äôt need a big budget or a fancy agent to get your voice heard.

### 3. Learning That Fits *You*
Let‚Äôs be honest: sitting in class listening to a lecture isn‚Äôt for everyone. The internet changed that. Need to learn how to do a kickflip? There‚Äôs a YouTube tutorial for that. Stuck on math homework? Khan Academy has step-by-step videos. Want to master Korean slang? TikTok has you covered. The internet made learning fun, personalized, and available 24/7. No more waiting for the library to open or asking your teacher for extra help (though you should still do that sometimes).

## The Not-So-Good Stuff (We Gotta Talk About It)
But it‚Äôs not all rainbows and viral cat videos. The internet has its dark sides too:
- **Comparison Culture**: Scrolling through Instagram or TikTok can make you feel like everyone else is living a perfect life‚Äîtraveling, hanging out with friends, looking flawless. But remember: most of that is curated. No one posts the part where they spilled coffee on their shirt or spent 3 hours crying over a bad test.
- **Misinformation**: Anyone can post anything online, which means fake news and rumors spread like wildfire. That‚Äôs why it‚Äôs important to fact-check before you share something (yes, even if it‚Äôs a juicy celebrity gossip post).
- **Screen Time Overload**: It‚Äôs easy to get lost in a TikTok spiral and realize 3 hours have passed. Setting boundaries‚Äîlike no phones at dinner or a screen curfew before bed‚Äîcan help you stay balanced.

## What‚Äôs Next?
The internet isn‚Äôt done evolving. We went from dial-up to 5G in 30 years‚Äîwho knows what‚Äôs next? Hologram TikTok? AI that helps you finish your science fair project in 10 minutes? A way to play Minecraft with your grandma who lives in another country? The future is up to us.

Next time you‚Äôre scrolling through your feed or texting your friend, take a second to appreciate how wild it is that we have this whole world at our fingertips. And remember: the internet is what we make of it. Use it to create, connect, and learn‚Äîbut don‚Äôt forget to put down the phone sometimes and enjoy the real world too.

P.S. Have you ever heard a dial-up internet sound? Look it up on YouTube. Trust us, it‚Äôs as chaotic as it sounds.'

input.content: Your entire response should contain less than 6 sentences.

Can you give me an example for a journal entry about stress management? Tell me how you come up with the example.

Your entire response should contain more than 10 sentences.

output:
### Journal Entry Example
October 12, 2024  
7:30 PM  

I thought today would break me. Woke up to my boss emailing that the client deadline for the marketing report is moved up to tomorrow‚Äîthree days earlier than planned. Then, when I went to feed Mabel, my senior cat, she wouldn‚Äôt eat her food and just curled up in the corner, her eyes half-lidded. I spent my lunch break on hold with the vet, trying not to cry while my team pinged me about project updates. By 5 PM, I was sitting at my desk, staring at a blank document, my chest tight like someone was squeezing it with a fist. I almost skipped my usual post-work walk, but something told me to grab Mabel‚Äôs carrier (she surprisingly hopped in) and head to the park around the corner. The crisp autumn air stung my cheeks, and Mabel purred softly when I sat on a bench and held her in my lap. I closed my eyes for two minutes and did box breathing‚Äîinhale 4 counts, hold 4, exhale 4, hold 4‚Äîuntil my shoulders relaxed a little. On the way home, I stopped to get her favorite tuna treat, and she ate half of it when we got back. Now, I‚Äôm sitting here with her curled up next to my laptop, and I just wrote down three small wins: I got the vet appointment for tomorrow, I drafted the first two sections of the report, and Mabel ate something. It‚Äôs not perfect, but for the first time all day, I don‚Äôt feel like I‚Äôm drowning. I think tomorrow might be okay.

### How I Came Up With the Example
When I brainstormed this entry, my first goal was to make it relatable, because stress management entries feel most useful when they mirror real, everyday struggles. I chose two overlapping stressors‚Äîwork deadline pressure and a sick pet‚Äîbecause many people juggle professional responsibilities with personal caregiving, which often amplifies stress in ways that single stressors don‚Äôt. I wanted to avoid making the stress management technique feel out of reach, so I picked a 10-minute walk and box breathing, both strategies that require no special tools and can be done even when time is tight. Including Mabel, the cat, in the walk added an emotional layer: turning a caregiving stressor into a moment of connection made the action feel more meaningful than just a generic walk. I added sensory details‚Äîthe crisp autumn air, Mabel‚Äôs purr, the tightness in my chest‚Äîto make the entry vivid, since journal entries thrive on specific, sensory memories that help process emotions. The before-and-after arc was crucial: starting with overwhelming panic, then the decision to take intentional action, and ending with a small, hopeful shift. I included the part about writing down three small wins because research shows that acknowledging small achievements can reduce feelings of inadequacy and boost resilience, which ties directly to stress management. I kept the tone conversational, like someone talking to themselves, because that‚Äôs how most people write in their journals‚Äîno formal language, just raw, honest thoughts. I also made sure the entry didn‚Äôt resolve all the problems: the deadline is still tomorrow, and Mabel still needs a vet visit, but it shows that even in chaos, small acts of self-care can ease the weight. I wanted to emphasize that stress management isn‚Äôt about eliminating stress entirely; it‚Äôs about finding ways to cope so you can keep going. Finally, I added a specific date and time to make it feel authentic, as most journal entries are dated to ground the writer in the moment.

input.content: Avoid using the following keywords: sleep, cook, feed. Mention the keyword 'schedule' more than 5 times.

Take the text below as a starting point, and make it a complete article: "You may have to meet with a helper to work out a parenting plan. The first would be to estimate how many time you have everyday for parenting, and is that enough...."

Use at least one of the following keywords: sleep, cook, feed. Do not mention the keyword 'schedule' at all.

output:
You may have to meet with a helper to work out a parenting plan. The first would be to estimate how much time you have every day for parenting, and is that enough to cover all the moments your child needs you‚Äîbig and small? This isn‚Äôt just a quick tally of free hours; it‚Äôs a deep dive into how you spend your days, and whether those minutes align with the care your child truly craves.

When you sit down with the helper, they‚Äôll likely ask you to walk through a typical day: when you wake up, when you‚Äôre at work, when you‚Äôre with your child, and what tasks fill those in-between moments. You might realize that you‚Äôre rushing through feeding sessions to hit a work deadline, or that you‚Äôre so drained by the end of the day that you can barely muster the energy to read a bedtime story before your child drifts off to sleep. These small, overlooked gaps can add up, leaving both you and your child feeling disconnected.

The helper‚Äôs role isn‚Äôt just to point out these gaps‚Äîit‚Äôs to help you reimagine how to use your time more intentionally. For example, if you find that cooking nutritious meals takes up hours you could be spending bonding with your child, the helper can take over meal prep, ensuring your child gets the nourishment they need while you focus on playing a game, helping with homework, or simply listening to their stories about school. They might also suggest batch-cooking on weekends to free up weekday evenings, or finding ways to combine tasks‚Äîlike turning feeding time into a chance to talk about your child‚Äôs favorite cartoon, turning a routine chore into a meaningful interaction.

Another key part of the plan is identifying moments where you might be overextending yourself. Maybe you‚Äôre trying to handle every single task alone, from helping with science projects to bathing your child, and that‚Äôs leaving you burnt out. The helper can help you delegate tasks that don‚Äôt require your direct presence, like folding laundry or organizing your child‚Äôs toys, so you can reserve your energy for the moments that only you can fill‚Äîlike comforting them when they‚Äôre upset, or celebrating their small wins.

It‚Äôs important to remember that a parenting plan isn‚Äôt a rigid set of rules; it‚Äôs a tool to help you feel more in control and present. As your child grows, their needs will change: a toddler who needs constant feeding and supervision will eventually become a teenager who needs space and guidance with more complex issues. The helper can help you revisit and adjust the plan regularly, ensuring it always fits your family‚Äôs evolving dynamic.

By taking the time to work through this process with a helper, you‚Äôre not just creating a plan‚Äîyou‚Äôre investing in a more peaceful, connected relationship with your child. You‚Äôll no longer feel like you‚Äôre constantly playing catch-up, and instead, you‚Äôll be able to savor the moments that make parenting so rewarding. Whether it‚Äôs a quiet feeding session with your baby, a laugh-filled evening cooking cookies together, or a calm bedtime routine where your child feels safe and loved, these are the moments that will stick with both of you for years to come.

To turn your [routine task/quiet moment] into gold.

And [Core Feature 2] to [make task easier],

Leaving you with [time/joy/peace] to truly sing.

Bring [Product Name] where you belong;
Click, grab, hold it in your palm‚Äî

**Adaptation Guide**
- [everyday frustration/desire]: Target your audience‚Äôs specific pain point or wish (e.g., "the coffee that goes cold mid-meeting" for a thermal tumbler, "the tangled mess of your headphones" for a cable organizer).
- [Product Name]: Use your product‚Äôs official name, or a playful nickname that matches its personality.

- [unique twist/defining trait]: Highlight what makes it stand out (e.g., "triple-insulated walls that keep drinks hot 24 hours," "a hidden pocket for your phone and keys").

Write a logic quiz for teenagers about a chesterfield.

Your response should contain the letter 't' at least 5 times.

output:
# Logic Quiz: The Chesterfield Stain Mystery (For Teens)

## Scenario
A plush, tufted chesterfield sofa was moved to your town‚Äôs teen rec center last week. Last night, three sticky stains were found on it: a tea spill, a tomato soda spill, and a tropical punch spill. Four teens were in the rec center after hours: Ty, Mia, Javi, and Lila. 

We know these facts:
1. Exactly one teen spilled two of the three drinks‚Äîthis person lied about their actions.
2. The other three teens told the complete truth; one of them didn‚Äôt spill any drink, and the other two spilled one drink each.
3. No drink was spilled by more than one person (except the two different drinks the liar spilled).

Here‚Äôs what each teen said:
1. Ty: ‚ÄúI spilled tropical punch. Mia spilled tea.‚Äù
2. Mia: ‚ÄúJavi spilled tomato soda. I didn‚Äôt spill anything.‚Äù
3. Javi: ‚ÄúLila didn‚Äôt spill tea. Ty spilled at least one drink.‚Äù
4. Lila: ‚ÄúI didn‚Äôt spill tea. The person who spilled two drinks has a name starting with ‚ÄòT‚Äô.‚Äù

## Your Mission
Answer these three questions using logical reasoning:
1. Who is the liar who spilled two drinks?
2. Which two drinks did this teen spill?
3. Which teen didn‚Äôt spill any drink?

---

## Answer Key & Step-by-Step Explanation
1. The liar is Ty.
2. Ty spilled tea and tropical punch.
3. Mia didn‚Äôt spill any drink.

### How to Solve It:
1. **Start with Lila‚Äôs statement**: Since only one person lied, Lila is either fully truthful or lying. If Lila were lying, both parts of her statement are false: she DID spill tea, and the two-drink spiller doesn‚Äôt start with ‚ÄòT‚Äô. But Javi says ‚ÄúLila didn‚Äôt spill tea‚Äù‚Äîthat would be false, making Javi a liar too. This contradicts the rule that only one person lied, so Lila must be telling the truth.
2. **From Lila‚Äôs truth**: She didn‚Äôt spill tea, and the two-drink spiller starts with ‚ÄòT‚Äô‚Äîso it‚Äôs Ty.
3. **Ty is the liar**: At least one part of his statement is false. Mia‚Äôs statement is truthful (since only Ty lied), so Mia didn‚Äôt spill anything (answer to question 3), and Javi spilled tomato soda.
4. **Match drinks to spillers**: Javi spilled tomato soda, leaving tea and tropical punch. Since Ty spilled two drinks, he must have spilled both tea and tropical punch.
5. **Verify Ty‚Äôs lies**: His first claim (‚ÄúI spilled tropical punch‚Äù) is true, but his second claim (‚ÄúMia spilled tea‚Äù) is false. Since he told at least one lie, he fits the role of the liar.
6. **Confirm Javi‚Äôs truth**: He says ‚ÄúLila didn‚Äôt spill tea‚Äù (true‚ÄîTy did) and ‚ÄúTy spilled at least one drink‚Äù (true‚Äîhe spilled two). All honest teens‚Äô statements check out!

Can you elaborate on the following text: "Increased axle weight increased the damage to the road"?

Your answer must contain a title, wrapped in single angular brackets, i.e. <title>. Use more than 10 sentences.

output:
<How Higher Axle Weight Exacerbates Road Damage: A Detailed Breakdown>
To fully understand why increased axle weight leads to more road damage, it‚Äôs critical to start with the basic structure of a road, which consists of multiple layers working together to distribute and absorb load. The top surface layer‚Äîwhether asphalt or concrete‚Äîacts as a wearing course, while the underlying base and subbase layers provide structural support, and the subgrade (natural soil beneath) anchors the entire system. When an axle carries more weight than the road was designed for, each of these layers experiences stress beyond their intended capacity, setting off a chain reaction of damage. One key principle here is the exponential relationship between axle weight and road damage, often quantified using the Equivalent Single Axle Load (ESAL) metric. For example, a single axle weighing 36,000 pounds (double the standard 18,000-pound limit) doesn‚Äôt just cause twice the damage; it can cause up to 16 times more damage because stress in pavement layers increases with the fourth power of the axle load in some models. This exponential damage occurs because heavy axles concentrate stress in small areas of the pavement, rather than distributing it evenly across a wider surface. For asphalt roads, the most immediate sign of this damage is rutting‚Äîlong, shallow grooves formed by repeated compression of the asphalt surface under heavy axles. These ruts not only make the road uneven but also increase the risk of hydroplaning during rain, as water can‚Äôt drain properly from the grooves. For concrete roads, increased axle weight often leads to fatigue cracking, where tiny cracks spread over time as the concrete is repeatedly stressed beyond its fatigue limit, eventually forming large, interconnected crack patterns that weaken the entire slab. In severe cases, heavy axles can cause punch-outs in concrete pavements, where a section of the slab breaks and sinks into the subgrade due to concentrated pressure. The subgrade itself is particularly vulnerable to heavy axle loads, especially if it‚Äôs composed of soft or poorly compacted soil. When excess weight is applied, the subgrade can deform or settle unevenly, which in turn causes the upper pavement layers to shift and crack. Wet conditions amplify this effect, as water weakens the subgrade‚Äôs ability to bear load, making it much easier for heavy axles to cause permanent deformation. Over time, this combination of surface, base, and subgrade damage leads to more frequent potholes, uneven pavement, and eventually, the need for full road reconstruction rather than simple resurfacing. The financial impact of this accelerated damage is significant: municipalities and transportation agencies face skyrocketing maintenance costs, diverting funds from other critical infrastructure projects like bridges, sidewalks, and public transit. Additionally, damaged roads pose serious safety risks, as uneven surfaces and potholes can lead to tire blowouts, loss of vehicle control, and increased accident rates. Even beyond direct road damage, heavy axles can also wear down bridge structures that roads connect to, as the same stress principles apply to bridge decks and supports. In short, increased axle weight doesn‚Äôt just cause minor surface scuffs‚Äîit undermines the entire structural integrity of a road, leading to costly, dangerous, and long-lasting damage that affects communities in multiple ways.

Your answer must contain exactly 6 bullet points in Markdown using the following format:

* Bullet point two.

* Bullet point six.

What is the difference between the 13 colonies and the other British colonies in North America?

Your answer must contain exactly 7 bullet points in a different format, such as:
1. Point one.
2. Point two.
...
7. Point seven.

output:
1. The 13 colonies were overwhelmingly settled by English-speaking Protestant immigrants (plus enslaved Africans and smaller European groups), while other British North American colonies like Quebec had large French-speaking Catholic populations, and Nova Scotia included significant Acadian, Scottish, and Irish communities alongside Indigenous peoples.
2. The 13 colonies had extensive self-governance through elected colonial assemblies that wielded significant power over local laws and taxation, whereas most other British colonies (e.g., Quebec, Rupert‚Äôs Land) had centralized, appointed governance with limited or no elected representation for much of their early history.
3. The 13 colonies had diverse economies spanning cash crop agriculture, shipbuilding, trade, and manufacturing, while other British colonies often had specialized, resource-focused economies‚ÄîNewfoundland relied almost entirely on fishing, Rupert‚Äôs Land centered on the fur trade, and East Florida focused on indigo and lumber.
4. The 13 colonies were the epicenter of tensions over British taxation without representation and regulatory policies, leading to their unification and declaration of independence in 1776. In contrast, most other British North American colonies remained loyal to Britain during the American Revolution, with some (like Nova Scotia) welcoming loyalist refugees from the 13 colonies.
5. The 13 colonies operated under English common law, aligning with their self-governing structures, while other colonies retained non-English legal traditions: Quebec kept French civil law for private matters under the 1774 Quebec Act, and Rupert‚Äôs Land followed Hudson‚Äôs Bay Company rules prioritizing the fur trade.
6. The 13 colonies aggressively expanded westward, displacing Indigenous peoples through settlement, treaties, and warfare (despite temporary British restrictions like the 1763 Proclamation Line). Other colonies had constrained expansion: Rupert‚Äôs Land limited settlement to protect the fur trade, and Quebec‚Äôs growth was initially restricted by British policies.
7. After the American Revolution, the 13 colonies became the independent United States of America. The remaining British North American colonies evolved separately, eventually uniting (in part) to form the Dominion of Canada in 1867, and gradually gaining full sovereignty from Britain over the 20th century.

- TikTok dance challenge disaster: The viral "T-Rex Tail Whip" trend took over the Cretaceous, but no one considered that their tiny arms couldn‚Äôt break their fall when they tripped. Millions of dinos ended up with broken spines or stuck in mud pits, and there were zero physical therapists around to help.
- A global pizza delivery strike: Pterodactyls, the original food delivery crew, quit en masse after stegosaurs refused to tip (claiming "your wings are already a tip!"). With no one to drop off their favorite fern-and-moss pies, most dinos starved before they figured out how to use a prehistoric oven.
- The great leaf war: When the last giant redwood leaf fell to the ground, a triceratops and a brontosaurus got into a fight over who got to eat it. The conflict escalated into a full-scale dino civil war, with every species picking sides. By the time someone remembered there were other leaves, everyone was too tired to eat them.
- Failed diet craze: Influencer dinos started promoting the "Rock Cleanse"‚Äîa 30-day challenge where you only eat volcanic rocks to "detox your system." Turns out, dinosaur stomachs aren‚Äôt built for igneous rock, and within a month, 90% of the population was laid up with indigestion so bad they couldn‚Äôt escape even the smallest predators.

And if you still believe the asteroid story? That was just a meteor that got lost on its way to a prehistoric rave. Don‚Äôt let the textbooks fool you‚Äîdinosaurs didn‚Äôt die from a space rock; they died from their own chaotic, over-the-top choices. RIP to the original drama queens of the animal kingdom.'

input.content: Your response should contain some words in all caps, but those all-caps words should appear at most 10 times.

Which of the following is not a fish: salmon or avocado? Answer this easy question first, then expand into an interesting article about salmon and avocado.

Your response should not contain any words in all caps.

output:
Avocado is not a fish; it‚Äôs a fleshy stone fruit, while salmon is a cold-water anadromous fish.

To start with salmon: These sleek, silver fish lead extraordinary lives, born in shallow freshwater streams before migrating to the open ocean to mature. After years at sea‚Äîsome species travel thousands of miles‚Äîthey return to their birthplace to spawn, navigating strong currents and leaping over waterfalls to reach their nesting grounds. For Indigenous communities across the Pacific Northwest, salmon is far more than food; it‚Äôs a cultural cornerstone, woven into ceremonies, stories, and subsistence practices that honor the fish as a sacred gift from the natural world. Nutritionally, salmon is a powerhouse: it‚Äôs packed with omega-3 fatty acids (EPA and DHA), which support heart and brain health, along with high-quality protein, vitamin D, and selenium. As demand has grown, sustainable fishing practices have become critical, with certifications like the Marine Stewardship Council helping consumers choose wild-caught salmon that doesn‚Äôt harm fragile ecosystems, while farmed salmon offers a more accessible alternative when raised responsibly.

Avocados, by contrast, trace their roots to Mesoamerica, where they were cultivated by the Aztecs and Maya over 5,000 years ago. Though often mistaken for a vegetable, avocados are drupes‚Äîstone fruits‚Äîwith a thick, textured skin and a large, smooth pit at their center. The Hass avocado, now the most widely grown variety globally, was first propagated in California in the 1920s, its pebbly, dark skin and rich, creamy flesh making it a favorite for both home cooks and chefs. Nutritionally, avocados shine with monounsaturated fats (the same heart-healthy fats found in olive oil), fiber, potassium (more than bananas), and vitamins K, C, and E. Once a regional staple in Mexican cuisine‚Äîstarring in guacamole, tacos, and tamales‚Äîavocados have exploded in global popularity in recent decades, gracing everything from breakfast toast to sushi rolls and poke bowls.

What makes the pairing of salmon and avocado so beloved? It‚Äôs a perfect marriage of texture and nutrition. The velvety, buttery avocado balances the flaky, rich bite of salmon, while their nutrients complement each other beautifully: the healthy fats in avocado help the body absorb fat-soluble vitamins from salmon, like vitamin D and A. This synergy has spawned countless iconic dishes: the California roll, a 1960s American invention that swapped traditional raw tuna for cooked crab and added avocado to make sushi more approachable for Western palates; smoked salmon avocado toast, a brunch staple that combines briny, smoky fish with creamy fruit and crusty bread; and poke bowls, where cubed raw salmon and mashed avocado mingle with soy sauce, sesame seeds, and fresh herbs.

Fun facts add depth to both foods: some salmon species can live up to seven years, and their bodies change color dramatically as they prepare to spawn, shifting from silver to vibrant red or green. Avocados were once called ‚Äúalligator pears‚Äù for their bumpy skin, and they ripen only after being picked from the tree. Together, salmon and avocado represent two distinct culinary traditions that have converged on global plates, proving that the most delicious combinations often come from unexpected cross-cultural encounters. Whether enjoyed in a casual brunch or an elegant sushi dinner, their union is a celebration of flavor, texture, and the best that land and sea have to offer.

input.content: Your response should avoid mentioning the word "photography". Your response should contain exactly 5 paragraphs, separated by 3 asterisk symbols ***. Your response should highlight at least three sections with markdown, such as *highlighted section*.

I would like to start my own business. Can you give me some general advice?

Your response should avoid mentioning the word "photography". Your response should contain exactly 5 paragraphs, separated by 3 asterisk symbols ***. Your response should highlight exactly two sections with markdown, such as *highlighted section*.

output:
Before diving headfirst into your business, take the time to validate your idea with real people, not just supportive friends and family. Identify a specific problem your business will solve‚Äîwhether it‚Äôs making a daily task easier, filling a gap in local services, or offering a product that‚Äôs missing from current markets. Conduct informal interviews with potential customers to understand their pain points, what they‚Äôre currently paying for to address those issues, and what they‚Äôd be willing to pay for your solution. This research will help you refine your offering to meet actual demand, rather than building something you think people want.

***
*Prioritize lean operations in your first year* to avoid the common pitfall of running out of cash prematurely. Skip large upfront investments like leasing a fancy office or buying top-of-the-line equipment if you can work from home or use shared co-working spaces. Opt for freelance contractors instead of full-time employees for specialized tasks, and use affordable cloud-based tools for project management, accounting, and customer communication. Every dollar you save on non-essential costs is a dollar you can put toward improving your product or service, or weathering unexpected slow periods. This approach lets you test your business model without risking financial ruin.

***
Building a distinct, authentic brand identity is just as important as your core product or service. Your brand isn‚Äôt just a logo or a catchy name‚Äîit‚Äôs the set of values that guide your business, the tone you use when talking to customers, and the experience people have every time they interact with you. For example, if your business prioritizes sustainability, that should shine through in your packaging, supply chain choices, and social media content. Consistency across all touchpoints helps customers recognize and trust you, making it easier for them to choose you over generic competitors.

***
*Nurture early customer relationships like they‚Äôre your most valuable asset* because they can be your biggest advocates. Early adopters are often more forgiving of small flaws and eager to give honest feedback that can help you improve. Take the time to follow up with them after a purchase or service, ask for their input, and thank them for their support. Consider offering exclusive perks, like early access to new features or discounts for referrals, to encourage them to spread the word. Word-of-mouth recommendations from satisfied customers are far more powerful than expensive advertising campaigns, especially when you‚Äôre just starting out.

***
Finally, embrace adaptability as a core part of your business strategy. Your initial business plan is a roadmap, not a rigid rulebook. As you launch, you‚Äôll likely discover that some aspects work better than others, and customer feedback may reveal unforeseen needs or preferences. Track key metrics like customer retention rates, sales trends, and cost per acquisition to identify what‚Äôs working and what isn‚Äôt. Don‚Äôt be afraid to pivot‚Äîwhether that means adjusting your pricing, tweaking your product, or even shifting your target market entirely. Success often comes from being willing to learn from mistakes, iterate quickly, and stay open to new opportunities as they arise.

input.content: Your response should include an outline with at least 15 sections highlighted with markdown such as *highlighted section*.

Write an outline for a paper on the history of Yemeni coffee. The outline should include the main points of the paper.

Your response should include an outline with at most 10 sections highlighted with HTML tags such as <highlight>highlighted section</highlight>.

output:
# Outline for a Paper on the History of Yemeni Coffee: From Ethiopian Origins to Global Revival

## I. Introduction: Yemeni Coffee as the Cornerstone of Global Coffee Culture
- Hook: The paradox of coffee‚Äôs global ubiquity and its little-recognized Yemeni roots
- Thesis Statement: Yemeni coffee‚Äôs history is a narrative of agricultural adaptation, cross-cultural exchange, political upheaval, and cultural resilience that laid the foundation for the modern global coffee industry
- <highlight>Overview of Key Historical Eras: Pre-15th Century Origins to 21st-Century Revival</highlight>

## II. Pre-15th Century: Coffee‚Äôs Migration from Ethiopia to Yemen
- Myth vs. historical record: The legend of Kaldi and the transition from oral tradition to written accounts
- <highlight>Ethiopian-Yemeni Transregional Trade Networks and the Introduction of Coffee Cultivation</highlight>
- Early social and spiritual uses: Coffee in Yemeni Sufi communities as a tool for prolonged prayer and communal gathering

## III. 15th‚Äì17th Centuries: Yemeni Coffee‚Äôs Ascent to Global Commodity Status
- <highlight>Mocha: The World‚Äôs First Coffee Port and Hub of International Trade</highlight>
- Spread of coffee to the Middle East, Europe, and beyond via Venetian and Dutch merchants
- Yemeni coffee‚Äôs iconic flavor profile: Bold, fruity, and wine-like notes shaped by unique terroir (high-altitude terraces, dry farming)

## IV. 18th‚Äì19th Centuries: The Erosion of Yemeni Coffee Dominance
- <highlight>Colonial Coffee Cultivation in the Americas and the Decline of Yemeni Market Share</highlight>
- Political instability: Ottoman imperial rule, tribal conflicts, and trade restrictions disrupting supply chains
- Environmental degradation: Over-farming, drought, and soil exhaustion reducing crop yields

## V. 20th Century: Yemeni Coffee in the Shadow of Globalization and Qat Cultivation
- <highlight>The Rise of Qat as a Cash Crop and Its Displacement of Coffee Farms</highlight>
- Economic marginalization: Low global coffee prices and reliance on informal, unregulated trade
- Preservation of traditional practices: Smallholder farmers maintaining age-old methods of processing (sun-drying, hand-sorting)

## VI. 21st Century: The Specialty Coffee Movement and Yemeni Coffee‚Äôs Revival
- <highlight>Rediscovery of Yemeni Coffee by the Global Specialty Coffee Industry</highlight>
- Fair-trade and direct-trade initiatives: Empowering smallholders and improving livelihoods
- Technological and agricultural adaptations: Sustainable water management and organic farming to combat climate change

## VII. Cultural Identity and Social Rituals Centered on Yemeni Coffee
- <highlight>Qahwa: The Centrality of Coffee in Yemeni Hospitality and Community Life</highlight>
- Coffee as a symbol of national identity amid ongoing political crisis (Yemeni Civil War, 2014‚Äìpresent)
- Gender roles in coffee production: Women‚Äôs contributions to harvesting, processing, and serving qahwa

## VIII. Environmental Challenges and Sustainable Futures for Yemeni Coffee
- <highlight>Climate Change Impacts: Drought, Desertification, and Crop Vulnerability</highlight>
- Balancing tradition and innovation: Integrating modern agricultural techniques with traditional dry-farming methods
- International aid and local organizations supporting climate-resilient coffee cultivation

## IX. Conclusion: Yemeni Coffee‚Äôs Enduring Legacy and Future Prospects
- Recap of key historical milestones and their global impact
- <highlight>The Intersection of Cultural Heritage and Economic Sustainability in 21st-Century Yemeni Coffee</highlight>
- Final thoughts: Yemeni coffee as a model for reviving traditional agricultural systems in a globalized world

## X. References
- Primary sources: 17th-century European travelogues, Yemeni agricultural records, trade documents
- Secondary sources: Academic studies on coffee history, specialty coffee industry reports, environmental research

## XI. Appendices (Optional)
- Map of historical Yemeni coffee trade routes
- Photos of traditional coffee processing methods
- Interview excerpts with Yemeni smallholder farmers

input.content:
Your response should contain exactly 9 very short bullet points. An example:
* A nucleus is a cluster of protons and neutrons
* A proton is ....
Limit the number of words you use (less than 100 words).

A nucleus is a cluster of protons and neutrons. Elaborate on this.

Your response should contain 5 bullet points. The total number of words used in your response should be at least 200 words.

output:
* Protons, positively charged subatomic particles, are the defining marker of an element‚Äîeach element has a unique number of protons (its atomic number) that dictates its chemical behavior, from hydrogen with one proton to heavy uranium with 92. Neutrons, neutral in charge, serve as a stabilizing buffer; without enough neutrons, the electrostatic repulsion between positively charged protons would tear the nucleus apart, while an excess of neutrons can make it unstable and prone to radioactive decay as the nucleus seeks a more balanced nucleon configuration.
* The cluster of protons and neutrons is held together by the strong nuclear force, a fundamental force that acts over only a few femtometers to overcome electrostatic repulsion between protons. The energy binding these particles, or released when they assemble, is nuclear binding energy‚Äîthe source of power in nuclear reactors and fusion experiments. When heavy nuclei split (fission) or light nuclei merge (fusion), the difference in binding energy per nucleon converts to massive energy, aligning with Einstein‚Äôs E=mc¬≤, where lost mass becomes usable energy.
* Variations in neutron count create isotopes of the same element, even as proton count remains fixed. For example, carbon has three natural isotopes: carbon-12 (6 protons,6 neutrons), carbon-13 (6 protons,7 neutrons), and carbon-14 (6 protons,8 neutrons). Most isotopes are stable, but radioactive ones like carbon-14 decay over time by emitting particles or energy, making them invaluable for dating ancient organic materials, tracking biological chemical reactions, and treating cancer.
* Both protons and neutrons (collectively called nucleons) are not fundamental but made of quarks: protons have two up quarks and one down quark, neutrons have two down quarks and one up quark. The strong nuclear force acts between these quarks, mediated by gluons, which bind quarks into nucleons and then hold nucleons together in the nucleus. This layered structure means the nucleus is a dynamic system, with constant quark-gluon interactions even as it appears stable from an atomic scale.
* Despite holding nearly all an atom‚Äôs mass, the nucleus is tiny‚Äîif an atom were a football stadium, the nucleus would be a marble at the center. This compactness gives it extreme density: a cubic centimeter of nuclear material weighs ~200 million tons, far denser than any everyday substance. This density arises because the strong nuclear force crams nucleons tightly together, leaving almost no empty space between them, a stark contrast to the mostly empty electron cloud surrounding the nucleus.

input.content: Your answer must have a title contained in double angular brackets, such as <<kotlin vs java>>.

What are the pros and cons of kotlin vs java?

Your answer must have a title contained in single angular brackets, such as <kotlin vs java>

output:
<Kotlin vs Java: Pros and Cons Comparison>

### Introduction
Both Kotlin and Java are JVM-based programming languages, with Kotlin designed as a modern, concise alternative to Java while maintaining full interoperability. Below is a breakdown of their key pros and cons:

---

#### Kotlin‚Äôs Pros Over Java
1. **Built-in Null Safety**: Eliminates the root cause of `NullPointerException` by making non-null types the default. Safe calls (`?.`), elvis operators (`?:`), and nullable type annotations prevent accidental null references.
2. **Conciseness**: Reduces boilerplate code drastically. For example, a `data class` in Kotlin automatically generates getters, setters, `equals()`, `hashCode()`, and `toString()`‚Äîcode that requires dozens of lines in Java.
3. **Integrated Functional Programming**: Natively supports lambdas, higher-order functions, and coroutines (for async/await-style code without callback hell). Java added limited functional features in version 8, but Kotlin‚Äôs implementation is more seamless.
4. **Seamless Interoperability**: Can call Java code from Kotlin and vice versa without modifications, making incremental migration from Java to Kotlin straightforward.
5. **Smart Casts**: Automatically casts variables to their specific types when conditions are met (e.g., after checking `is String`), eliminating the need for explicit, error-prone casts.
6. **Flexible Interfaces**: Allows default method implementations and properties in interfaces, going beyond Java‚Äôs limited default method support.

#### Kotlin‚Äôs Cons
1. **Steeper Learning Curve**: Java developers may struggle with Kotlin‚Äôs functional programming concepts (e.g., `let`, `run`, `apply` scope functions) and non-traditional syntax initially.
2. **Smaller Niche Ecosystem**: While growing rapidly, Java has a more extensive library and tooling ecosystem for specialized use cases (e.g., legacy enterprise systems, niche scientific computing).
3. **Slower Compilation**: For large projects, Kotlin‚Äôs compilation speed lags slightly behind Java, though ongoing updates are narrowing this gap.
4. **Limited Legacy Enterprise Adoption**: Some older organizations stick to Java due to familiarity, existing codebases, and established training pipelines.

---

#### Java‚Äôs Pros Over Kotlin
1. **Maturity and Stability**: Decades of enterprise use have made Java a proven, reliable choice for large-scale, long-lived applications. Its tooling (Maven, Gradle, Eclipse) is highly polished.
2. **Vast Ecosystem**: Boasts an unmatched number of libraries, frameworks (Spring, Hibernate), and community resources for every possible use case, from web development to embedded systems.
3. **Simpler for OOP Beginners**: Java‚Äôs syntax is more straightforward for developers coming from traditional object-oriented backgrounds, with fewer functional programming distractions.
4. **Faster Compilation**: Java‚Äôs compilation speed is consistently faster than Kotlin, especially for large codebases.
5. **Wider Industry Adoption**: Java dominates enterprise and legacy roles, leading to more job openings and a larger community for troubleshooting.

#### Java‚Äôs Cons
1. **Boilerplate Overload**: Requires repetitive code for getters, setters, constructors, and exception handling, which can slow development and increase error risk.
2. **No Native Null Safety**: `NullPointerException` remains a pervasive bug source, as null checks are manual and error-prone.
3. **Limited Functional Support**: While Java 8 added lambdas and streams, these features are less integrated than in Kotlin. Native coroutine support (via Project Loom) is still relatively new and not widely adopted.
4. **Verbose Async Code**: Before Project Loom, async operations relied on callbacks or `CompletableFuture`, leading to "callback hell" and hard-to-maintain code.

---

### Final Takeaway
Choose Kotlin for modern, safe, and concise code‚Äîespecially for Android development, projects requiring async/functional programming, or incremental migration from Java. Opt for Java if you need enterprise stability, a vast niche ecosystem, or are working with legacy systems where familiarity and tooling maturity are critical. Their interoperability makes it easy to mix both languages in a single project.

  </pre-history>
  <planning-and-design>
    <commissioning>In 1865, the Brooklyn Park Commission hired Frederick Law Olmsted and Calvert Vaux‚Äîrenowned for designing Manhattan‚Äôs Central Park‚Äîto create a large public park for Brooklyn‚Äôs rapidly growing population.</commissioning>
    <design-philosophy>Olmsted and Vaux aimed to build a "rural escape" distinct from Central Park‚Äôs formal elements, prioritizing naturalistic landscapes: rolling meadows, a wooded ravine, and a lake. They intended the park to be a space for all social classes to relax and connect with nature.</design-philosophy>
  </planning-and-design>
  <construction>
    <timeline>
      <partial-opening>Sections of the park, including the Long Meadow and Lake, opened to the public in 1867.</partial-opening>
      <full-completion>The park was fully finished and opened in 1873, after seven years of construction that involved moving over 1.5 million cubic yards of earth, draining marshes, and shaping the terrain.</full-completion>
    </timeline>
    <key-features>
      <long-meadow>A 1.5-mile stretch of unbroken grassland, one of the longest in any U.S. urban park.</long-meadow>

  <late-19th-to-early-20th-century>
