    <adjacent-developments>
      <lefferts-historic-house>In 1918, an 18th-century Dutch Colonial farmhouse was moved to the park to serve as a rural life museum.</lefferts-historic-house>
      <brooklyn-botanic-garden>Established adjacent to the park in 1910, it became a complementary cultural and educational institution.</brooklyn-botanic-garden>
    </adjacent-developments>
  </late-19th-to-early-20th-century>
  <mid-20th-century-challenges>
    <decline>Mid-century budget cuts, urban neglect, and rising crime led to a period of decline. Many natural features fell into disrepair, and some areas became unsafe for visitors.</decline>
    <wpa-contribution>The Works Progress Administration (WPA) built the Prospect Park Bandshell in 1935, which remains a core venue for outdoor events.</wpa-contribution>
  </mid-20th-century-challenges>
  <restoration-and-revival>

## Initial User Prompt Handling
This section covers the chatbot‚Äôs first interaction with a user to gather necessary data for weather updates. The chatbot opens with a friendly line asking the user to share a spot they want a forecast for. It should also offer examples of valid inputs, such as a city name, zip code, nearby landmark, to guide users who may not know how to phrase their request. If a user shares vague info, like ‚Äúnear a lake,‚Äù the chatbot will ask for more specific details to ensure accurate data retrieval. It may also prompt users to enable spot detection services for automatic, real-time updates if they‚Äôre using a mobile device.

## Spot Data Validation & Fetch
In this section, the chatbot processes the user‚Äôs input to confirm it‚Äôs a valid spot. It connects to a weather data API to check if the input maps to a recognized area; if not, it prompts the user to re-enter their request with clearer details. Once a valid spot is confirmed, the chatbot pulls real-time and forecast data from the API, including temp highs, lows, precipitation chances, and wind speeds. It also filters data to focus on time frames users frequently care about‚Äîlike hourly updates for the next 12 hours, daily updates for the next 5 days. The chatbot stores the valid spot temporarily so users can request updates for the same spot without re-entering details later.

## Forecast Delivery & Follow-Up
This section outlines how the chatbot presents data to the user in a clear, easy-to-read format. It starts with a confirmation of the spot, then lists key forecast points using bullet points and short lines for readability. The chatbot also asks if the user wants additional details, such as UV index, humidity levels, alerts for severe weather. If the user requests more info, it pulls and displays that data promptly; if not, it offers to check forecasts for other spots, and can also revisit the same spot later if the user asks. It also sends gentle reminders if the user opted in for daily updates, ensuring they stay informed about changing weather conditions. The chatbot ends each interaction with a thank-you note, encouraging users to get in touch again for future forecast needs.

# Planning Doc: User Authentication Module Refactoring with MFA Support
## Task Overview & Scope
This task focuses on refactoring the existing password-only user authentication module for the Acme SaaS platform to support multi-factor authentication (MFA) via Time-Based One-Time Password (TOTP) and SMS. The current system was flagged in the latest security audit as high-risk due to lack of secondary verification, exposing user accounts to brute-force attacks and credential stuffing. The primary goals are to: 1) Extend the backend user data model to store MFA secrets, preferences, and verified contact methods; 2) Build frontend UI components for MFA setup, verification, and preference management; 3) Integrate with Twilio for SMS code delivery and the pyotp library for TOTP generation/verification; 4) Ensure backward compatibility so users can opt into MFA without disrupting existing login workflows. Success metrics include zero auth-related downtime during deployment, a 90% adoption rate of MFA among active users within three months, and passing the next quarterly security audit with no high-risk findings related to authentication.

###

## Implementation Details & Dependencies
The implementation will follow a backend-first approach to solidify core functionality before frontend integration. Backend steps include: extending the PostgreSQL User table with columns for totp_secret, sms_phone_number, mfa_enabled, and mfa_preference; creating REST API endpoints for `/api/mfa/setup`, `/api/mfa/verify`, `/api/mfa/toggle`, and `/api/mfa/resend-code`; adding rate limiting to MFA verification endpoints to prevent brute-force attacks; and integrating Twilio‚Äôs SMS API with error handling for failed deliveries. Frontend work will involve building a step-by-step MFA setup flow (including a QR code generator for TOTP scanning, phone number verification for SMS, and preference selection), updating the login screen to conditionally prompt for an MFA code if enabled, and adding in-app tooltips to guide users. Key dependencies include a valid Twilio API key (to be provided by DevOps), the pre-approved pyotp Python library, and coordination with QA to develop end-to-end test cases for edge cases like expired codes and invalid phone numbers.

###

## Timeline & Risk Mitigation
The project will be completed over a 5-week timeline with phased milestones: Week 1‚Äì2: Backend implementation and unit testing, including integration with Twilio and pyotp. Week 3: Frontend UI development and API integration, followed by internal team testing. Week 4: User Acceptance Testing (UAT) with 50 power users, bug fixes, and a security review by the cybersecurity team. Week 5: Phased rollout to 10% of active users, real-time monitoring for issues, and full platform-wide rollout by week‚Äôs end. Key risks and mitigations include: 1) SMS delivery failures: Mitigate by adding an email-based MFA fallback and a secondary SMS provider. 2) User confusion with setup: Mitigate by publishing a help center article and embedding contextual in-app guides. 3) Performance degradation: Mitigate by load testing MFA endpoints with 10x normal traffic and optimizing database queries for secret retrieval. Post-launch, the team will monitor auth failure rates and support tickets to resolve unforeseen issues within 24 hours.

# Dive Into Wonder: My Unforgettable Day at Ripley‚Äôs Aquarium in <city name>

Rainy afternoons in <season> can feel like a total buzzkill‚Äîuntil you trade the drizzle for a world of coral reefs, gliding sharks, and glowing jellyfish. Last weekend, I convinced my eye-rolling <family member> to join me at Ripley‚Äôs Aquarium in <city name>, and by the time we left, they were already scrolling the website for tickets to their next special event. If you‚Äôre craving an escape from the ordinary, this underwater oasis is an absolute must-visit.

Our first stop was the Dangerous Lagoon, and it set the tone for the entire day. As we stepped into the <underwater tunnel length> glass tunnel, I felt my breath catch. A 12-foot tiger shark glided directly overhead, its fins cutting through the water like silk, while a gentle green sea turtle lazily swam past, pausing as if to say hello. The tunnel‚Äôs moving walkway let us take it all in at our own pace, and I found myself stopping every few feet to snap photos (and maybe gawk a little) at the schools of tropical fish darting through the coral.

Next up was the Touch Tank Lagoon, a favorite for kids and kids at heart alike. I was nervous to dip my hand in at first, but the friendly staff encouraged me to pet a horseshoe crab‚Äîits shell felt like smooth, ancient armor. <family member>, who‚Äôd been complaining about ‚Äúwasting a perfectly good Saturday‚Äù an hour earlier, ended up spending 20 minutes chatting with a trainer about stingrays, even working up the courage to let one glide through their fingers. It was a sweet reminder that even the most skeptical among us can be won over by a little marine magic.

No trip to Ripley‚Äôs is complete without visiting the <favorite sea creature> Exhibit, and let me tell you‚Äîit was showstopping. The dimly lit room was filled with tanks of jellyfish in every hue imaginable: neon pink, electric blue, and soft lavender. They pulsed gently to the sound of calming ambient music, and I could have stood there for hours, mesmerized. Halfway through our visit, we caught a talk by <marine biologist name>, a passionate expert who explained how jellyfish survive without brains or hearts. It was equal parts fascinating and humbling, and it made me appreciate these otherworldly creatures even more.

By mid-afternoon, our stomachs were growling, so we headed to the aquarium‚Äôs caf√©. To my delight, they had a pop-up from <local snack vendor>, a beloved spot in <city name> known for their crispy fish tacos. We grabbed a couple of tacos and a side of coconut rice, then ate while watching otters play in their enclosure nearby. It‚Äôs the little touches like this‚Äîpartnering with local businesses to highlight regional flavors‚Äîthat make Ripley‚Äôs feel more than just a tourist trap.

Before we left, we stopped by the front desk to ask about upcoming events, and we were thrilled to learn they‚Äôre hosting a ‚ÄúShark Sleepover‚Äù on <special event date>. For anyone who‚Äôs ever wanted to camp out under the sea, this is your chance: participants get to sleep in the Dangerous Lagoon tunnel, enjoy a behind-the-scenes tour, and even help the staff feed the sharks at dawn. <family member> immediately added it to our calendar, and I can‚Äôt blame them.

On our way out, we popped into the souvenir shop and picked up a glowing <souvenir shop item>‚Äîa tiny jellyfish nightlight that now sits on my bedside table. Every time I turn it on, I‚Äôm transported back to that tunnel, watching sharks glide overhead and feeling like I was part of something bigger.

Ripley‚Äôs Aquarium in <city name> isn‚Äôt just a place to look at fish‚Äîit‚Äôs a place to connect with the ocean, learn something new, and make memories that stick. Whether you‚Äôre traveling with a group of friends, your kids, or flying solo, there‚Äôs something here to spark your curiosity. Don‚Äôt forget to check their website for updates on exhibits and special events like the one on <special event date>‚Äîyou won‚Äôt want to miss out on the magic.

List the pros and cons of using two different names for the same thing.

Your response should not contain the word "synonyms" at all.

output:
### Pros of Using Two Different Names for the Same Thing  
1. Contextual adaptability: Different names often fit better in specific settings. For example, a technical term might be appropriate in a professional report, while a simpler, everyday name works better in casual conversations with non-experts, making communication more effective for diverse audiences.  
2. Cultural or regional resonance: A name may feel more familiar or meaningful to a particular community, helping to build trust and ensure understanding across cultural or regional divides. This can make discussions more inclusive and relatable.  
3. Highlighting distinct attributes: Two names can emphasize different features of the same thing. For instance, a food item might have one name that references its origin and another that describes its taste, giving people a more nuanced understanding of what it is.  
4. Reducing repetition: Using alternative names can make writing or speech feel more dynamic and engaging, avoiding the monotony that comes from repeating the same term repeatedly in long texts or extended conversations.  

### Cons of Using Two Different Names for the Same Thing  
1. Risk of confusion: People may not recognize that the two names refer to the same item, leading to misunderstandings. This is especially problematic in high-stakes settings like healthcare or engineering, where clarity is critical to safety and accuracy.  
2. Increased learning complexity: For someone new to a topic, navigating two names for the same concept adds unnecessary layers of difficulty, slowing their ability to absorb and retain information.  
3. Inconsistent documentation: In formal records, technical manuals, or databases, using multiple names can create inconsistencies, making it harder to organize, search for, or retrieve information efficiently.  
4. Exclusionary potential: If one name is widely known in a dominant group but unfamiliar to a marginalized community, failing to clarify the connection between the two can leave some people feeling overlooked or unable to participate fully in conversations.

Nestled between sunbaked hills and a slow-moving river, there‚Äôs a tiny town where the thermometer never dips below or rises above 90¬∞F. It‚Äôs a place where porch swings creak in the stagnant air, and every window has a screen propped open year-round. Sarah has called this town home since she was a toddler, and she‚Äôs never known a day without this steady, humid warmth.

## Sarah‚Äôs Clever Heat Survival Rituals
Sarah, who‚Äôs spent decades adapting to the unchanging heat, has a set of daily rituals that keep her feeling refreshed. Each morning, she starts with a glass of iced lemonade, then spends an hour tending to her shade-loving potted plants on the north side of her house. She avoids going outside during the midday hours, preferring to read or knit in her cool, basement living room instead. Even when visitors complain about the constant warmth, Sarah just laughs and says, ‚ÄúYou get used to it‚Äîeventually!‚Äù

## The Limerick Honoring Sarah‚Äôs Steamy Abode
There once was a gal named Sarah,
Who lived where it‚Äôs always 90, hurrah!
She sipped iced brew all day,
Chased shade where she may,

input.content: In your response, separate your thinking and the final answer by a line with just three "*" symbols: ***. At the end of your response, please explicitly add a postscript starting with P.P.S

A colt is 5 feet tall. It will grow 6 inches every month. How tall will it be in 3 years? Think step-by-step, then give your answer.

Your response should contain a single paragraph without any separation. Do not include any postscript or additional text after the main content.

output: To determine how tall the colt will be in 3 years, start by converting the time period to months since the growth rate is given per month: 3 years multiplied by 12 months per year equals 36 months. Next, calculate the total amount the colt will grow in inches: 6 inches per month times 36 months is 216 inches. Since the initial height is in feet, convert the total growth to feet by dividing by 12 (as 1 foot equals 12 inches): 216 inches divided by 12 inches per foot is 18 feet. Then add the colt's initial height of 5 feet to the total growth of 18 feet to get the final height: 5 + 18 = 23 feet. This result can be verified by converting the initial height to inches first (5 feet = 60 inches), adding the total growth (60 + 216 = 276 inches), and converting back to feet (276 √∑ 12 = 23 feet), confirming the final height is 23 feet.

output:
# Extravagant 3-Day Java Immersive Bootcamp: From Foundations to Cloud Native Mastery
A curated, high-end learning experience designed for 20 handpicked participants, blending expert mentorship, immersive activities, luxury amenities, and real-world application to transform Java proficiency.

## Venue Overview
All sessions take place in a custom-fitted, sun-drenched penthouse in a downtown tech hub, with floor-to-ceiling windows, modular workstations, and a dedicated lounge area stocked with artisanal coffee, craft mocktails, and gourmet snacks. Each participant receives a premium laptop (loaded with the latest Java 21 tools, custom IDE themes, and pre-configured cloud environments) and a personalized swag bag: leather notebook, wireless mechanical keyboard, gold-embossed Java logo pen, and a custom tumbler from a local roaster.

---

### Day 1: Legacy, Foundations, and Interactive Onboarding
**Core Objective**: Master Java fundamentals while connecting with its iconic legacy.

- **9:00‚Äì10:30 AM: Opening Keynote with a Java Pioneer**  
  A 90-minute talk by a former Java Champion and ex-Sun Microsystems engineer, who shares never-before-told anecdotes from Java‚Äôs "Oak" prototype days, demos early applets on vintage 1990s hardware (curated exclusively for the session), and maps Java‚Äôs evolution to modern enterprise tech. Attendees get a signed copy of the engineer‚Äôs rare memoir about the birth of Java.

- **11:00 AM‚Äì2:00 PM: Foundations Workshop (Tracked by Skill Level)**  
  Split into beginner, intermediate, and advanced groups led by senior Java developers:
  - **Beginner Track**: "Java Syntax Escape Room" ‚Äì Teams solve puzzles by writing basic code (variables, loops, conditionals) to unlock digital clues, with the winning team earning a 1-year subscription to JetBrains tools.
  - **Intermediate Track**: "OOP Deep Dive" ‚Äì Build a mini e-commerce cart using encapsulation, inheritance, and polymorphism, with 1:1 feedback from mentors and real-time code visualization via a custom interactive tool.
  - **Advanced Track**: "JVM Internals Masterclass" ‚Äì Dissect JVM memory management with live demos of garbage collection algorithms, using a specialized tool that visualizes heap allocation in 3D.

- **2:00‚Äì3:30 PM: Gourmet Farm-to-Table Lunch**  
  A catered meal paired with a fireside chat by a Spring Framework core contributor, who demos building a REST API in 15 minutes and answers questions about Java‚Äôs role in modern microservices.

- **4:00‚Äì6:30 PM: Immersive JVM Tuning Lab**  
  Participants use premium profiling tools (JProfiler, VisualVM) to optimize a poorly performing mock ride-sharing backend. The team that achieves the highest throughput wins a private tour of a major cloud data center.

- **7:00‚Äì9:00 PM: Networking Cocktail Hour**  
  Craft cocktails named after Java concepts (e.g., "Lambda Martini," "Object-Oriented Old Fashioned") and a live demo of a Java-powered IoT smart wine cellar, built by a local startup founder.

---

### Day 2: Advanced Concepts & Cloud Native Innovation
**Core Objective**: Master concurrency, microservices, and cloud deployment.

- **9:00‚Äì11:30 AM: VR Concurrency Simulation**  
  A one-of-a-kind VR experience where participants "step into" a JVM to visualize thread execution, deadlocks, and race conditions. They rearrange virtual threads to fix synchronization issues, with real-time feedback from a Google performance engineering expert.

- **12:00‚Äì2:30 PM: Microservices Build Challenge**  
  Teams build a full-stack microservices architecture using Spring Boot, Docker, and Kubernetes, with access to dedicated AWS clusters. Activities include:
  - Deploying services to the cloud and competing in a "Traffic Battle Royale" to handle 10,000 simulated user requests without downtime (metrics displayed on a giant LED wall).
  - 15-minute 1:1 office hours with cloud native Java experts to troubleshoot deployments or refine architecture.

- **2:30‚Äì4:00 PM: Sushi Lunch with a Netflix Engineer**  
  A catered sushi spread paired with a talk by a Netflix senior Java engineer, who explains how Java powers the streaming giant‚Äôs global content delivery network and shares best practices for scalable code.

- **4:30‚Äì7:00 PM: AI & Java Integration Workshop**  
  Participants build a Java backend for an AI chatbot using the OpenAI API, with guidance from a machine learning engineer. The most creative chatbot (judged on functionality and personality) wins a 6-month subscription to OpenAI‚Äôs GPT-4 Turbo.

- **7:30‚Äì9:00 PM: Sunset Hackathon Kickoff**  
  Teams form to work on a Java project of their choice (e.g., IoT controller, game engine, enterprise workflow tool). Each team gets a budget to use premium APIs and access to a 24/7 support line with Java developers.

---

### Day 3: Capstone Showcase & Industry Connections
**Core Objective**: Present projects to industry leaders and secure mentorship opportunities.

- **9:00‚Äì12:00 PM: Capstone Refinement**  
  Teams polish their projects with guidance from mentors, including professional designers to help create sleek demo presentations. Wellness breaks include a 20-minute yoga session to stretch after coding.

- **12:00‚Äì1:30 PM: Luxury Brunch & Networking**

output: ALL FIVE COMMANDOS HUG THE SHADOWS OF THE DUSTY SECTOR, THEIR INFRARED GOGGLES CASTING GREEN HALOS OVER THE CRUMBLING CONCRETE WALLS AND OVERGROWN ALLEYS. THE NIGHT WRAPS AROUND THEM LIKE A THICK, SILENT BLANKET, DROWNING OUT ALL SOUNDS EXCEPT THE SOFT CRUNCH OF GRAVEL UNDER THEIR BOOTS AND THE FAINT HUM OF THEIR COMS UNITS. JAX KICKS OPEN THE DOOR, AND THE TEAM SWINGS IN, WEAPONS RAISED. INSIDE, THEY FIND A SMALL COOP, ITS WIRE MESH TORN, BUT NO SIGN OF ANY LIVING BEING‚ÄîONLY A FEW FRAYED FEATHERS SCATTERED ON THE DIRT FLOOR. SUDDENLY, A DISTANT EXPLOSION ROCKS THE GROUND, SENDING DUST RAINING DOWN FROM THE CEILING. JAX BARKS INTO HIS COM, ‚ÄúMOVE! THAT‚ÄôS OUR EXTRACTION SIGNAL‚ÄîWE‚ÄôVE GOT TEN MINUTES BEFORE THIS SECTOR IS LOCKED DOWN.‚Äù THE TEAM RETREATS QUICKLY, THEIR FOOTSTEPS NOW URGENT, AS THE NIGHT GROWS EVEN DARKER, HIDING THEM FROM ANY POTENTIAL THREATS LURKING IN THE SHADOWS.

input.content: Your article must end with the exact phrase "Is there anything else I can help with?". No other words should follow this phrase.

Write an article about the reality of disability.

Your article must end with the exact phrase "Thank you for reading.".

output:
**The Unseen Reality of Disability: Beyond Stereotypes and Barriers**  

When we hear the word ‚Äúdisability,‚Äù many of us default to a narrow, often tragic, image: a person confined to a wheelchair, unable to participate fully in daily life, defined by their limitations. But this stereotype is a far cry from the lived reality of disabled people‚Äîa reality shaped not just by physical or cognitive differences, but by the ableist structures and assumptions that surround us every day.  

Disability is not a single, monolithic experience. It encompasses visible conditions like mobility impairments, and invisible ones like chronic fatigue syndrome, autism, or post-traumatic stress disorder. For someone with an invisible disability, the reality might involve pushing through a work meeting while battling unmanageable pain, or explaining for the hundredth time why they can‚Äôt stay late at a social gathering. These moments are rarely seen by others, yet they define much of their daily lives. People often assume they‚Äôre ‚Äúfaking it‚Äù or ‚Äújust being lazy,‚Äù unaware of the internal struggle or the accommodations they need to function.  

A critical shift in understanding disability comes from the social model, which argues that disability is not caused by a person‚Äôs impairment, but by the barriers society places in their way. A wheelchair user isn‚Äôt disabled because of their wheelchair‚Äîthey‚Äôre disabled because most public buildings lack ramps, most public transit isn‚Äôt accessible, and many employers see their wheelchair as a ‚Äúproblem‚Äù rather than a tool for independence. Similarly, a Deaf person isn‚Äôt disabled by their inability to hear; they‚Äôre disabled by a world that prioritizes spoken language over sign language, and fails to provide interpreters in schools, hospitals, and workplaces.  

Contrary to the myth of disabled people as ‚Äúvictims,‚Äù disabled communities are filled with agency, resilience, and innovation. Disabled activists have led the charge for accessibility laws like the Americans with Disabilities Act (ADA) in the U.S., and continue to advocate for better representation in media, politics, and all areas of life. Disabled artists, writers, and scientists bring unique perspectives to their work‚Äîthink of Temple Grandin, whose autism gave her insights into animal behavior that revolutionized livestock handling, or Alice Wong, whose work as a disability activist and writer has centered disabled voices in mainstream conversations.  

Yet, too often, non-disabled people speak over disabled voices, making decisions about their lives without their input. We design public spaces without considering accessibility, create workplaces that don‚Äôt offer flexible hours for people with chronic conditions, and tell disabled people what ‚Äúthey should be able to do‚Äù instead of listening to their needs. This ableism‚Äîprejudice or discrimination against disabled people‚Äîis the real barrier, not disability itself.  

The reality of disability is that it‚Äôs a natural part of human diversity. Just like race, gender, or sexuality, disability is not a flaw to be fixed; it‚Äôs an identity to be respected. Disabled people don‚Äôt need pity‚Äîthey need access, equality, and the chance to live their lives on their own terms.  

To be an ally, start by listening. Ask disabled people what they need, instead of assuming. Advocate for accessible public spaces, inclusive policies, and representation in media. Challenge ableist jokes or comments when you hear them. Small acts can add up to big change.  

Disability is not a tragedy. It‚Äôs a reality that millions of people navigate every day, with joy, frustration, and everything in between. The more we see disabled people as full, complex humans‚Äîrather than stereotypes‚Äîthe closer we get to a world where everyone can thrive.  

Thank you for reading.

input.content: Your response must be written in the Persian language, no other language is allowed.

Write a weird poem about yoda being transported into a different universe.

Your response must be written in English, no other language is allowed.

output:
**Yoda in the Glitterverse**  

The Force split like an overripe bantha fruit‚Äî  
A crack of static, burnt blue milk, and hoot.  
Spun Yoda, his cane a twig in chaos‚Äôs mouth,  
Till stars dissolved to glitter, south to north, to south.  

Land he did on ground that breathed, that hummed,  
A meadow where dandelions drummed.  
A toaster waddled by, chrome and smug,  
Its dial spinning out a sonnet‚Äôs hug.  

‚ÄúWho are you, green thing, ears like folded leaves?‚Äù  
It asked, crumbs of philosophy on its sleeves.  
Tilted Yoda his head, eyes wide as saucers:  
‚ÄúLost am I. Where the Force is, these saucers?‚Äù  

The sky was pink, clouds dripped honeyed rain,  
A moon was a rubber duck, bobbing plain.  
A doorknob winked, then sang a sea shanty,  
Gravity yawned, let Yoda float, then tugged‚Äîlazy.  

‚ÄúStrange this place, but not unkind,‚Äù he said,  
As the toaster taught him how to butter bread  
With a spoon made of starlight, warm and thin.  
‚ÄúThe Force here‚Ä¶ not light or dark, is it? Sin?  
No‚Äîhum of things that are, it is. The rhyme  
Of toaster, the meadow‚Äôs distant chime.  
A new Force, this is,‚Äù Yoda nodded slow,  
‚ÄúNot of swords, but of the weird and glow.‚Äù  

Now sits he atop the rubber duck moon,  
Teaching toasters how to croon  
About burnt toast and hope‚Äôs soft balance,  
While the doorknob claps, clouds elope in dance.  
‚ÄúHome is where the weirdness wraps around,‚Äù  
Yoda says, as stars make a sound‚Äî  
A giggle, a crunch, a toaster‚Äôs cheer,  
In a universe where nothing‚Äôs clear,  
But everything is exactly what it needs to be:  
A little bit weird, a little bit free.

Write an essay on the topic of navigable freeway.

Your response must be in all uppercase letters, no lowercase letters allowed. Your response must be no more than 300 words long.

output:
NAVIGABLE FREEWAYS ARE THE ENGINEERED BACKBONE OF MODERN TRANSPORT, CRAFTED TO ENABLE UNINTERRUPTED, SAFE, AND EFFICIENT MOVEMENT OF VEHICLES ACROSS CITIES AND REGIONS. WHAT SETS A NAVIGABLE FREEWAY APART IS ITS METICULOUS ATTENTION TO DESIGN, MAINTENANCE, AND REAL-TIME MANAGEMENT DETAILS.

CLEAR, STRATEGIC SIGNAGE IS NON-NEGOTIABLE: LARGE, REFLECTIVE SIGNS WITH UNIVERSAL SYMBOLS MUST BE PLACED FAR IN ADVANCE, GIVING DRIVERS AMPLE TIME TO PLAN LANE CHANGES WITHOUT DISTRACTION. REFLECTIVE LANE MARKINGS, EVEN IN LOW-LIGHT OR ADVERSE WEATHER CONDITIONS, PREVENT LANE DRIFT AND GUIDE MERGING VEHICLES SAFELY. WELL-DESIGNED RAMPS ARE ANOTHER CRITICAL FEATURE: ON-RAMPS PROVIDE SUFFICIENT ACCELERATION SPACE FOR VEHICLES TO MATCH FREEWAY SPEEDS, WHILE OFF-RAMPS ALLOW GRADUAL DECELERATION WITHOUT DISRUPTING THROUGH TRAFFIC.

ADAPTIVE TRAFFIC MANAGEMENT SYSTEMS, SUCH AS VARIABLE SPEED LIMITS AND DIGITAL REAL-TIME CONGESTION UPDATES, HELP MAINTAIN STEADY FLOW BY ALERTING DRIVERS TO HAZARDS, ACCIDENTS, OR BACKUPS AHEAD. REGULAR MAINTENANCE‚ÄîFILLING POTHOLES, REPAIRING FADING MARKINGS, AND REPLACING BROKEN SIGNS‚ÄîENSURES THE FREEWAY REMAINS NAVIGABLE AND HAZARD-FREE OVER TIME. DEDICATED LANES, LIKE HOV OR TRUCK LANES, ACCOMMODATE DIVERSE VEHICLE TYPES, REDUCING CONGESTION AND IMPROVING OVERALL SAFETY.

ULTIMATELY, A NAVIGABLE FREEWAY IS MORE THAN A PAVED ROAD; IT‚ÄôS A COORDINATED SYSTEM THAT SAVES TIME, REDUCES DRIVER STRESS, AND SUPPORTS ECONOMIC ACTIVITY BY KEEPING GOODS AND PEOPLE MOVING SEAMLESSLY ACROSS COMMUNITIES.

output:
Create a blog post that shares the most captivating sights, unexpected encounters, and memorable rides experienced while traveling on public transportation.

# Public Transit‚Äôs Hidden Gems: The Rides and Moments That Stuck With Me  

If you think public transit is just a utilitarian way to get from point A to point B, you‚Äôre missing out on one of life‚Äôs most underrated story hubs. It‚Äôs a moving theater, a cross-section of human life, and sometimes, a portal to unexpected joy. Over the years, I‚Äôve hopped on buses, subways, trams, and even a few quirky regional trains, and these are the moments that still make me smile (or pause) when I think about them.  

## The Subway Poetry Slam That Stole the Show  
It was a rainy Tuesday evening in Boston, and the Red Line was running 20 minutes late. Commuters slouched in their seats, scrolling mindlessly on phones, when a guy in a faded flannel shirt stood up, cleared his throat, and said, ‚ÄúY‚Äôall look like you need a pick-me-up. Let me share something I wrote this morning.‚Äù What followed was a 10-minute impromptu poetry slam about the beauty of rainy commutes and the strangers we share our quiet moments with. By the end, even the grumpiest-looking businessman was clapping. No microphones, no stage‚Äîjust a subway car full of people, united by a few verses about the chaos of daily life.  

## The Vintage Streetcar That Felt Like a Time Machine  
Last summer, I took a trip to New Orleans and hopped on the St. Charles Avenue Streetcar. This isn‚Äôt your average tram; it‚Äôs a historic green-and-cream beauty that‚Äôs been rolling since 1835. The wooden seats creaked, the conductor called out stops in a slow, drawling accent, and as we trundled past oak trees draped in Spanish moss and colorful shotgun houses, I felt like I‚Äôd stepped into a postcard. What made it even better? A local couple sitting next to me shared stories of growing up riding this same streetcar, pointing out hidden jazz clubs and family-owned po‚Äô boy shops along the route. It wasn‚Äôt just a ride‚Äîit was a crash course in NOLA‚Äôs soul.  

## The Bus Commuter Who Knit for Shelter Dogs  
Every Wednesday for six months, I rode the same morning bus to work in Chicago. There was always a woman in a bright blue hat sitting in the back, knitting furiously. One day, I asked her what she was making. She held up a tiny, striped sweater and said, ‚ÄúThese are for the puppies at the shelter downtown. They get cold in the winter, and sweaters make them more likely to get adopted.‚Äù Over the weeks, I watched her turn skeins of yarn into tiny coats, scarves, and even a few doggy hats. By the time I switched jobs, she‚Äôd made over 50 pieces. That bus ride stopped feeling like a chore; it felt like a weekly check-in with someone who was quietly making the world a little warmer.  

## The Night Train That Turned Into a Sing-Along  
On a late-night train from Berlin to Hamburg, I was the only passenger‚Äîuntil we picked up a group of three musicians carrying guitars and an accordion. They sat across from me, ordered a round of beers from the snack cart, and started playing folk songs in German. I didn‚Äôt understand all the lyrics, but the melody was infectious. Soon, even the train conductor joined in, tapping his foot and humming along. By the time we reached Hamburg, we were all laughing and exchanging contact info. It was a reminder that public transit doesn‚Äôt just connect places‚Äîit connects people.  

Public transit isn‚Äôt just about efficiency; it‚Äôs about the unexpected. It‚Äôs the stranger who shares their story, the historic ride that feels like a time machine, and the small acts of kindness that make a long commute worth it. Next time you‚Äôre on a bus or train, put your phone down. You never know what hidden gem you might find.

As requested: Write a blog post about the most interesting things you have seen or ridden on public transportation.

Could you tell me what kind of balls are used in tennis? I would like the answer in the form of a medieval style poem.

Your response should not include any postscripts (P.S., P.P.S., etc.).

output:
**The Courtly Sphere**  

Beneath the turret‚Äôs shadowed span,  
Where nobles clash with rod and plan,  
A sphere of skill doth dance and bound‚Äî  
The heart of this old courtly round.  

Not forged of steel nor hewn of stone,  
But stitched with care, soft threads alone;  
Wound tight with wool from fleeces fair,  
Or horsehair plucked to bear the wear.  

Some clad in leather, tanned and brown,  
To weather blows that would break down  
A weaker orb; some bare of hide,  
Their cloth-bound frames with pride abide.  

They fly o‚Äôer nets of twisted cord,  
Through air where courtly cheers are stored;  
Each bounce a note in chivalry‚Äôs song,  
This humble ball, where play doth throng.  

So listen well, ye who would know  
The sphere that makes the courtly show:  
‚ÄôTis stitched with craft, stuffed with soft things,  
A small but mighty king of wings.

# The Rainbow Cafe: Queer-Owned Community Hub Operational & Identity File

Part 1: Mission & Core Values  
The Rainbow Cafe is a queer-founded, community-centered space dedicated to celebrating LGBTQIA+ joy, fostering belonging, and serving delicious, accessible food and drinks. Our core values guide every decision we make:  
- **Radical Inclusivity**: We welcome all people‚Äîregardless of gender identity, sexual orientation, race, ability, immigration status, or economic background‚Äîwith zero tolerance for discrimination, microaggressions, or exclusionary behavior.  
- **Community First**: We prioritize lifting up local queer creators, organizers, and nonprofits, using our space as a platform for connection rather than just commerce.  
- **Accessibility**: We offer sliding-scale pricing, dietary-inclusive menu options, and physical accommodations (e.g., ramps, quiet spaces for neurodivergent guests) to ensure no one is turned away.  
- **Joy as Resistance**: We believe in centering queer joy through vibrant events, playful menu items, and a warm, unapologetically queer atmosphere that feels like home.

Part 2: Menu Offerings (Queer-Themed & Inclusive)  
Our menu is designed to reflect the diversity of the queer community, with options for every dietary need (vegan, gluten-free, nut-free, and more). Standout items include:  
- **Drinks**:  
  - Non-Binary Nectar: A floral iced tea blend of lavender, hibiscus, and lemon, sweetened with agave (served with a pronoun pin garnish).  
  - Pride Punch: A rotating seasonal fruit punch (summer: watermelon-mint; winter: spiced apple) with a rainbow-colored edible glitter rim.  
  - Trans Tonic: A calming herbal latte with chamomile, oat milk, and a dash of cinnamon, named in honor of trans resilience.  
- **Food**:  
  - Drag Queen Delight Sandwich: A loaded grilled cheese with caramelized onions, roasted tomatoes, and vegan cheddar, served with a side of "Sashay Fries" (crinkle-cut fries with rainbow seasoning).  
  - Ace Avocado Toast: A simple, savory toast with mashed avocado, everything bagel seasoning, and a sprinkle of red pepper flakes‚Äîcrafted for guests who prefer subtle, no-fuss flavors.  
- **Special Events Menu**: Monthly drag brunch feasts with bottomless mimosas, pancake stacks dyed rainbow, and a side of live drag performances.

Part 3: Safe Space Policies & Community Commitments  
We‚Äôve built intentional policies to ensure The Rainbow Cafe is a true safe space for all:  
- **Staff Training**: All team members complete 8 hours of LGBTQIA+ cultural competency training annually, including modules on pronoun usage, gender identity basics, and supporting trans and non-binary guests.  
- **Physical Space**: Gender-neutral restrooms with all-gender signage, private nursing/quiet rooms for neurodivergent guests or those needing a break, and free pronoun pins available at the front counter.  
- **Community Initiatives**:  
  - Weekly Queer Open Mic: A space for queer poets, musicians, and storytellers to share their work (no cover charge, with free coffee for performers).  
  - Monthly Support Group Meetings: We host free space for local trans youth support groups and queer senior coffee hours.  
  - Nonprofit Partnerships: 10% of sales on the 15th of every month go to local queer organizations, including the Trans Justice Coalition and Queer Youth Housing Initiative.

Part 4: Staff & Team Culture  
As a queer-owned business, we prioritize creating a supportive, empowering work environment for our team:  
- **Hiring Equity**: We actively recruit queer, trans, non-binary, and gender-nonconforming staff, and prioritize candidates from marginalized queer communities (e.g., BIPOC queer folks, disabled queer folks).  
- **Team Support**: Staff receive paid time off for gender-affirming care, access to free mental health resources through a queer-led therapy collective, and monthly staff-led affinity groups to discuss workplace needs.  
- **Leadership**: Our founder, Riley (they/them), is a non-binary queer community organizer with 10 years of experience advocating for LGBTQIA+ rights. They lead monthly team check-ins to ensure every voice is heard and valued.

Part 5: Customer Engagement & Future Goals  
We strive to build long-term, meaningful connections with our guests and grow our impact:  
- **Customer Feedback**: Monthly "Community Input Nights" where guests can share ideas for menu items, events, or policy changes, with a free pastry for all participants.  
- **Loyalty Program**: The "Rainbow Rewards" program gives points for every purchase, redeemable for free drinks, drag brunch tickets, or limited-edition queer-themed merchandise (e.g., rainbow tote bags, pride-themed mugs).  
- **Future Goals**:  
  - Expand to a second location in a neighborhood with limited queer-owned businesses by 2026.  
  - Launch a catering service specializing in queer events (weddings, gender reveal parties, pride parades).  
  - Establish the "Rainbow Culinary Scholarship" to support queer youth pursuing careers in the food industry, with full tuition coverage for a local culinary school program.

## Section-by-Section Explanation  

### 1. Contact Information  
**Purpose**: Provides recruiters with immediate, easy access to your professional channels. Including LinkedIn and GitHub is critical for software engineers, as they showcase your professional network and hands-on coding skills.  
**Benefit**: Ensures recruiters can reach you quickly and verify your technical expertise via your GitHub portfolio.  

### 2. Professional Summary  
**Purpose**: A concise elevator pitch (2‚Äì3 lines) that distills your core value proposition. It‚Äôs designed to grab a recruiter‚Äôs attention within 5 seconds, as most spend only 7‚Äì10 seconds scanning a resume initially.  
**Benefit**: Highlights your 7 years of experience, key technical skills, and quantifiable achievements (e.g., 35% latency reduction) to position you as a high-impact candidate before recruiters dive into details.  

### 3. Core Competencies  
**Purpose**: A scannable list of keywords tailored to software engineering roles, optimized for Applicant Tracking Systems (ATS) and human recruiters.  
**Benefit**: ATS tools prioritize resumes with relevant keywords (e.g., ‚ÄúAWS,‚Äù ‚Äúmicroservices‚Äù), so this section ensures your resume passes initial screening. It also lets recruiters quickly confirm you match their tech stack requirements.  

### 4. Professional Experience  
**Purpose**: The most critical section of your resume, where you prove your impact using action verbs and quantifiable results (the STAR method: Situation, Task, Action, Result).  
**Benefit**: By focusing on measurable achievements (e.g., ‚Äúreduced deployment time by 90%,‚Äù ‚Äúincreased conversion rates by 22%‚Äù), you avoid generic statements and demonstrate you can deliver tangible value to employers. Leading a team and mentoring juniors also showcases leadership potential, a key trait for senior roles.  

### 5. Technical Projects  
**Purpose**: Complement your professional experience by highlighting initiative, passion for coding, and skills you may not use in your full-time role (e.g., open-source contribution).  
**Benefit**: For software engineers, side projects or open-source work signal you‚Äôre proactive and stay current with emerging technologies. The FastAPI-Validation project here demonstrates expertise in Python, community collaboration, and problem-solving for real developer pain points.  

### 6. Education  
**Purpose**: Validates your foundational technical knowledge and shows you have the academic background to succeed in software engineering.  
**Benefit**: A CS degree is a standard requirement for many tech roles, and relevant coursework reinforces your expertise in key areas like distributed systems and cloud computing. Including GPA (if 3.5+) adds credibility.  

### 7. Certifications  
**Purpose**: Provides third-party validation of your technical skills, especially in cloud computing‚Äîan in-demand area for modern software engineering.  
**Benefit**: Certifications like AWS Certified Solutions Architect or Google Cloud Professional Developer prove you have specialized, industry-recognized expertise, making you stand out from candidates with only self-reported skills. They also align with many job descriptions that require cloud proficiency.

input.content: Your response must be 100 words or less. Make sure to highlight at least 2 sections in your answer with markdown, i.e. use *highlighted section*.

Write an extremely short essay on the role of mythology in the work of Jordan Peterson. Be general in your writing.

Your response must be more than 150 words. Make sure to highlight at least 2 sections in your answer with markdown, i.e. use ## Highlighted Section.

output:
Jordan Peterson‚Äôs work is defined by his radical reclamation of mythology as a foundational lens for understanding human psychology, morality, and societal order. Rejecting the modern tendency to dismiss myths as primitive fiction, he frames them as distilled, cross-cultural wisdom that encodes the universal struggles of the human condition‚Äîbetween chaos and order, vulnerability and strength, individual responsibility and collective belonging.

## Myth as a Blueprint for Psychological Order
Peterson draws heavily from Carl Jung‚Äôs archetypal psychology to argue that myths are not arbitrary stories but maps for the human psyche. For example, he interprets the biblical story of Adam and Eve‚Äôs expulsion from Eden not as a historical account, but as a narrative that mirrors the moment an individual gains self-awareness, confronting the weight of moral choice and the inevitability of suffering. These archetypal narratives, he contends, help individuals navigate the chaos of unstructured existence by providing recognizable patterns for making sense of their own fears, desires, and conflicts. In this way, myth becomes a tool for integrating the unconscious mind with conscious action, fostering psychological stability.

## Myth as a Tool for Moral Grounding
In an era marked by secular nihilism and widespread alienation, Peterson positions mythology as a counterweight to moral relativism. He argues that cross-cultural myths consistently emphasize the importance of personal responsibility, courage, and the rejection of victimhood‚Äîvalues he sees as eroding in modern society. The hero‚Äôs journey, a universal mythic structure, is a cornerstone of this argument: Peterson frames it as a metaphor for the individual‚Äôs struggle to confront their own flaws, overcome adversity, and contribute meaningfully to their community. By recontextualizing this archetype, he encourages his audience to embrace hardship as a path to growth, rather than a reason for despair.

Ultimately, Peterson‚Äôs engagement with mythology is not about promoting religious dogma, but about reviving a shared language of human experience that transcends time and culture. For him, myths are the quiet architects of human flourishing, offering timeless lessons that help individuals find purpose in a world often stripped of meaning.

output:
'Sonia, I‚Äôve been wanting to ask you something ever since you mentioned that new matcha caf√© downtown last week‚Äîwould you be free to join me there this Saturday morning? I noticed you raved about their honey toast, and I‚Äôve been curious to try it too, plus I‚Äôd love to hear more about your recent hike in the national forest. Keeping it specific and tied to something she‚Äôs shared shows you listen, which makes the question feel personal instead of generic, and the low-key setting takes the pressure off so she can say yes without overthinking it.

***

Before you ask, take a quick moment to gauge her mood‚Äîif she‚Äôs relaxed, making eye contact, and actively participating in your chat, that‚Äôs the perfect window to bring it up. Avoid asking when she‚Äôs rushed, stressed, or surrounded by a lot of people, since that might make her feel put on the spot. Phrasing it as an option rather than a demand (like ‚Äúwould you be up for‚Ä¶‚Äù instead of ‚Äúyou have to come with me‚Äù) gives her space to decline gracefully if she wants, which helps keep the interaction positive no matter the answer.

***

If she says yes, respond with genuine excitement‚Äîmaybe something like ‚ÄúAwesome, I‚Äôll pick you up at 10 or meet you there, whatever‚Äôs easier for you‚Äù to keep things flexible. If she declines, don‚Äôt take it personally; a simple ‚ÄúNo worries at all, maybe another time?‚Äù keeps the door open without making her feel awkward. The key is to be yourself‚Äîauthenticity goes a lot further than trying to be someone you‚Äôre not, and Sonia will appreciate the honesty whether she accepts or not.'

input.content: Your response must not include the words 'can' and 'ride'.

Write a story for kids about how a person learns to ride a bike.

Your response must include the words 'can' and 'ride' at least once.

output:
Lila‚Äôs sparkly pink bike had been her favorite thing for a whole year, but lately, she‚Äôd been staring at it differently. Her best friend Mia could ride without training wheels, zooming up and down the sidewalk like a little wind fairy, and Lila‚Äôs chest felt tight with wanting to do the same.

One sunny Saturday, Dad noticed her frowning at the bike‚Äôs wobbly training wheels. ‚ÄúWant to give it a go without them?‚Äù he asked, kneeling down to meet her eyes. Lila nodded, her hands twisting the hem of her polka-dot dress.

Dad unscrewed the training wheels and set them aside. He held the back of the bike seat as Lila climbed on, her butterfly bell jiggling with every nervous shift. ‚ÄúKeep your eyes straight ahead,‚Äù he said. ‚ÄúPedal slow and steady.‚Äù

Lila pressed her feet to the pedals and pushed. The bike wobbled at first, but Dad‚Äôs strong hands kept her from tipping. She pedaled a few feet, her heart thumping, and then‚Äîsuddenly‚Äîshe felt the seat lighten. Dad had let go.

For three whole seconds, Lila rode all by herself, the wind tickling her cheeks. Then she looked down, panicked, and wobbled into the soft grass. She didn‚Äôt get hurt, just laughed as she sat up, grass in her hair.

‚ÄúDid you see that?‚Äù Dad cheered, running over. ‚ÄúYou just rode ten feet all on your own! You can do this, Lila‚Äîyou‚Äôre already halfway there.‚Äù

Lila‚Äôs grin grew. She climbed back on the bike, this time gripping the handlebars a little tighter. She took a deep breath, pushed the pedals, and started moving. This time, she kept her eyes on the oak tree at the end of the driveway, not looking down. The bike swayed once, then steadied. She rode all the way to the mailbox, rang her butterfly bell, and turned around, pedaling back to Dad.

‚ÄúI did it!‚Äù she yelled, jumping off the bike. ‚ÄúI can ride my bike without training wheels!‚Äù

Just then, Mia zoomed up on her blue bike. ‚ÄúWow, Lila! Let‚Äôs ride to the park together!‚Äù

Lila hopped back on her pink bike, rang her bell, and pedaled after Mia. The wind blew through her hair, and every time she pressed the pedals, she felt like she could fly. From that day on, the sidewalks and park paths were full of the sound of Lila‚Äôs butterfly bell and her happy shouts as she learned to ride faster, farther, and even do tiny little turns. She never looked at her training wheels again‚Äîbecause now, she knew she could ride anywhere her heart wanted to go.

input.content: Whenever the user inputs a request, first repeat the request word for word without change, then give your answer (do not say any words or characters before repeating the request). Your response must contain a title wrapped in double angular brackets, i.e. <<title>>.

Write a story about a man who is trying to get his life together.

First paraphrase the request in your own words, then give your answer. Start your response with the phrase "Here is my response:". Your answer must contain a title, wrapped in single angular brackets, i.e. <title>

output:
Here is my response:
Paraphrase: Create a story focused on a man who is actively working to turn his struggling, unbalanced life around and rebuild meaningful connections and stability.

<The Scratch on the Dining Table>

Leo stared at the chipped mug in his hand, the coffee gone cold hours ago. It was 9 a.m., and he should have been at a job interview, but he‚Äôd bailed at the last minute‚Äîold habits of self-sabotage creeping in. For the past two years, his life had unraveled like a frayed thread: he‚Äôd lost his construction job after a DUI, stopped talking to his sister Lila after a fight over their dad‚Äôs tools, and spent most nights drinking alone in his cramped studio apartment.

But last week, he‚Äôd found a photo in a box under his bed: him and Lila, 12 and 10, sanding a dining table their dad had started before he got sick. There was a deep scratch on the leg‚ÄîLeo‚Äôs mistake, when he‚Äôd gotten distracted by a butterfly and slipped with the sander. Dad had laughed and said, ‚ÄúScratches aren‚Äôt flaws. They‚Äôre just places we get to try again.‚Äù

That phrase had been ringing in his ears ever since. So yesterday, he‚Äôd called the local woodworking co-op and asked about their apprenticeship program. Today‚Äôs interview was his chance, but when he‚Äôd stood outside the door, his hands had started shaking, and he‚Äôd run.

Now, he grabbed his jacket and keys. He wasn‚Äôt going to the interview‚Äînot yet. First, he needed to fix the thing that had been weighing on him most: his relationship with Lila.

He drove to her house, his heart thudding. When she opened the door, her face was tight, like she was ready to shut him out. ‚ÄúWhat do you want, Leo?‚Äù

He held up the photo. ‚ÄúI found this. And I‚Äôm sorry. For everything. For the fight, for not being there when Mom‚Äôs birthday came around, for being a mess.‚Äù

Lila‚Äôs eyes softened. She stepped aside, and Leo walked in. The first thing he saw was the dining table‚Äîtheir dining table‚Äîsitting in the corner of her living room, the scratch still visible on the leg.

‚ÄúI kept it,‚Äù she said, following his gaze. ‚ÄúDad would‚Äôve killed me if I got rid of it.‚Äù

That night, they sat at the table and talked for hours. Lila told him she‚Äôd been worried sick, that she‚Äôd left a dozen voicemails he never returned. Leo admitted he was scared to try again, scared he‚Äôd mess up.

‚ÄúScratches aren‚Äôt flaws,‚Äù Lila said, quoting their dad. ‚ÄúWe get to try again.‚Äù

The next morning, Leo showed up at the woodworking co-op 15 minutes early. His hands still shook, but this time, he didn‚Äôt run. The interviewer, a quiet man named Hank, noticed the calluses on Leo‚Äôs hands and asked about them. Leo told him about the dining table, about the scratch, about his dad.

Hank smiled. ‚ÄúWe don‚Äôt need perfect workers here. We need people who know how to fix things.‚Äù

Six months later, Leo was sanding a custom bookshelf for a family with two young kids. He‚Äôd just finished filling a small scratch in the wood when his phone buzzed. It was Lila: ‚ÄúDinner at my place tonight. Dad‚Äôs table is set.‚Äù

When he arrived, the table was polished, the scratch still there but less noticeable, like a memory that no longer stung. Lila had made their dad‚Äôs favorite meatloaf, and for the first time in years, Leo felt like he was home.

He looked at the scratch on the leg, and for the first time, he didn‚Äôt see a mistake. He saw proof that he‚Äôd tried, failed, and tried again. And that was enough.

<The Print Swap>

Elara Voss, a former cybercriminal turned cybersecurity consultant, is desperate to clear her younger sister‚Äôs name after the girl was framed for a corporate data breach that used a fingerprint matching Elara‚Äôs old criminal record. Kael Rainer, a privileged tech heir, is on the brink of being exposed for siphoning millions from his family‚Äôs foundation, and he needs a clean set of prints to access a hidden offshore account that holds evidence of his innocence‚Äîor so he claims. When their paths cross at a black-market biotech clinic in a rain-soaked Bangkok alley, they strike a risky deal: Elara will let Kael use her ‚Äúclean‚Äù post-rehabilitation prints to access the account, and Kael will lend Elara his untainted prints to plant at the breach site and exonerate her sister. The swap requires a series of painful, temporary skin grafts that leave both of them with throbbing fingertips and a constant fear of being caught, and as they navigate the aftermath, they begin to uncover secrets about each other that threaten to unravel their fragile alliance. Elara discovers Kael‚Äôs embezzlement is real, but he was coerced into it by a shadowy associate who is also the mastermind behind her sister‚Äôs frame-up, while Kael learns Elara‚Äôs past is more tangled than she let on, with ties to the same criminal network that‚Äôs now hunting them both. input.content: Your response should include the keywords 'atlantis' and 'constable'.

output:
Research Project Proposal: Co-Designed Adaptive Tech Frameworks for Enhancing Disabled Quality of Life

Executive Summary

This project addresses critical gaps in accessible technology by centering people with disabilities as lead co-designers of adaptive tools tailored to their daily needs. Focused on physical, sensory, and cognitive impairments, the research will develop iterative, scalable solutions to reduce barriers to independent living, social participation, and emotional well-being. Over 24 months, the project will combine qualitative needs assessments, hands-on prototyping, and real-world testing to create open-source toolkits and guidelines that empower disabled individuals, caregivers, and tech developers to build inclusive environments.

Research Objectives

  • Map unmet accessibility needs through interviews with 60 disabled participants, 20 caregivers, and 10 accessibility specialists across urban and rural contexts.
  • Co-design 3-5 adaptive tech prototypes (e.g., voice-controlled sensory adjustment tools, cognitive support reminders, physical mobility aids) with disabled co-design teams.
  • Validate prototype impact using metrics like independent task completion time, social engagement frequency, and self-reported quality of life scores.
  • Launch a free, publicly accessible toolkit with step-by-step guides, open-source code, and funding resources for replicating inclusive adaptive tech solutions.

Methodology

Phase 1: Needs Assessment & Community Engagement (Months 1-6)

Recruit participants via disability advocacy organizations and local community groups. Conduct semi-structured interviews and focus groups to explore daily challenges, existing tech frustrations, and desired solutions. Analyze data using thematic coding to prioritize high-impact needs (e.g., kitchen accessibility, emergency response, social connection tools).

Phase 2: Co-Design & Prototyping (Months 7-14)

Form 3 cross-disability co-design teams. Use human-centered design workshops (storyboarding, rapid prototyping, usability testing) to draft initial solutions. Iterate on prototypes monthly based on participant feedback, ensuring compatibility with low-cost, widely available devices (e.g., smartphones, smart speakers) to maximize accessibility.

Phase 3: Real-World Testing & Impact Measurement (Months 15-20)

Deploy prototypes in 25 participant homes for 3-month trials. Collect quantitative data (task completion rates, emergency response times) and qualitative data (weekly check-ins, final feedback surveys) to measure improvements in independence and well-being. Compare outcomes to baseline data collected in Phase 1.

Phase 4: Toolkit Development & Dissemination (Months 21-24)

Synthesize findings into a comprehensive toolkit, including prototype blueprints, user guides, and policy recommendations. Host virtual workshops for disability organizations and tech developers, and publish research in accessibility journals to drive industry-wide adoption of inclusive design practices.

Expected Outcomes

  • Validated adaptive tech prototypes that reduce daily task completion time by 30% on average for participants.
  • A free, open-source toolkit downloaded by 15,000+ users within the first year of release.
  • 3 peer-reviewed publications highlighting the value of disabled-led co-design in tech development.
  • Partnerships with 2 major tech companies to integrate inclusive design principles into their consumer products.

Timeline

Phase Duration Key Milestones
Needs Assessment Months 1-6 Recruit all participants; publish needs assessment report
Co-Design & Prototyping Months 7-14 Finalize 3 functional prototypes; complete 3 iterative feedback cycles
Real-World Testing Months 15-20 Complete home trials; analyze impact data
Toolkit & Dissemination Months 21-24 Launch toolkit; host 2 national workshops; publish final research paper

Budget Estimate

Category Cost (USD) Justification
Participant Stipends $50,000 Compensation for 60 participants ($800 each) and 30 experts ($200-$500 each) for time and input
Prototype Materials $35,000 Smart devices, adaptive hardware, software licenses, and testing equipment
Research Staff $90,000 Salaries for 2 full-time researchers and 1 accessibility consultant over 24 months
Outreach & Dissemination $20,000 Workshop hosting, toolkit printing, conference fees, and digital outreach
Contingency $15,000 Unforeseen expenses (equipment repairs, additional recruitment)
Total $210,000

Conclusion

This project redefines accessible

input.content: Highlight at least 5 text sections using "*". For example: *3 years of experience*.

Write a cover letter for a job at a local coffee shop in the form of a poem.

Highlight at least 5 text sections using "<>". For example: <3 years of experience>.

output:
To the folks behind Maple & Steam‚Äôs chipped oak bar,  
Where the air hums with cinnamon and distant guitar‚Äî  
I‚Äôve lingered outside, nose pressed to fogged glass,  
Watching you turn beans into something that lasts.  

I‚Äôm the one who walks when the streetlights still glow,  
<early riser who brews before the sun peaks>‚Äî  
No alarm clock needed; my feet know the way  
To the grinders, the steam, the start of the day.  

I‚Äôve got <years of latte art practice (roses, hearts, even a wonky fox)>  
And a <knack for remembering regulars‚Äô orders by heart>‚Äî  
Marge‚Äôs oat milk macchiato, extra foam,  
Jake‚Äôs black coffee, hot as his morning commute home.  

I hold <certified in safe food handling and espresso machine maintenance>  
And last winter, I stood where the cold winds would bite,  
<volunteered at the neighborhood‚Äôs winter soup kitchen last year>  
Serving warm drinks to folks who needed a light.  

What draws me to you isn‚Äôt just the perfect pour,  
It‚Äôs how you ask about a kid‚Äôs soccer score,  
How you tape up handwritten poems on the wall,  
How you make every stranger feel like they belong, after all.  

I don‚Äôt just want a spot behind your bar‚Äî  
I want to be part of the stories you jar,  
The laughter, the sighs, the quiet ‚Äúthank you‚Äùs soft-spoken,  
Turning each cup into a moment unbroken.  

So if you‚Äôve got a spot for someone who cares,  
Who knows that good coffee‚Äôs more than just pairs  
Of beans and hot water‚Äîwho sees the heart in the steam‚Äî  
I‚Äôm ready to join your Maple & Steam team.  

With a bag of my grandma‚Äôs chocolate chip cookies (for taste-testing, of course),  
I‚Äôll be by at 10‚Äîlet‚Äôs talk, if you‚Äôve got the time to converse.  

Warmly,  
The girl with the coffee-stained notebook and calloused hands

### song: draft 17

verse 1:
rain streaks the window of the corner caf√©
your old flannel hangs on my chair, still smells like cedar and regret
i stir my coffee, watch the steam curl into "i'm sorry"
but the words died in my throat when i slammed the door that february

wishing i'd paused before i let the silence drown us out

should've let you in instead of building walls made of pride and despair

you said you loved me, i smiled, but i didn't say it back, didn't let it show

wishing i'd stopped to listen before the damage was done

chorus (repeat):
oh, draft 17 sits in my notes, unread, unsent
i rephrase the "i was wrong" till my fingers are bent
i should've held your hand when you said you were scared
should've let you in instead of building walls made of pride and despair
draft 17's a ghost that haunts my phone every night
wishing i'd fixed what i broke before it turned into goodbye

bridge:
i found your old mix tape in the back of my closet today
the first track's the one we danced to in your mom's kitchen, rainy may
i press play, and your voice comes through, a message i never heard
"i'm sorry i messed up, but i need you more than words"
i sit on the floor, and i finally cry, after all these years
regret's a song that plays on repeat, no matter how many times i hit clear

outro:
rain streaks the window of the corner caf√©
your old flannel hangs on my chair, still smells like cedar and regret
i open my notes, pull up draft 17, and delete it again
some words are too late to say, even when you wish you can

---

### explanations

title: "draft 17"
taylor often uses specific, personal-sounding titles that hint at the song‚Äôs core (like "all too well" or "cardigan"). the number 17 nods to her frequent use of numerical motifs (13, 22, 1989) and emphasizes the repetition of trying to fix unsaid words‚Äî17 drafts mean this regret has been replayed and reworked countless times, a relatable detail for anyone who‚Äôs overthought an apology.

verse 1:
taylor‚Äôs songwriting relies heavily on sensory, specific imagery to ground emotional moments (think the scarf in "all too well"). the corner caf√©, cedar-scented flannel, and steam curling into "i‚Äôm sorry" create a tangible scene that makes the regret feel immediate. the line about slamming the door in february ties to her use of seasonal references to mark pivotal moments (like "february" in "all too well (10 minute version)"), anchoring the conflict in a specific, memorable time.

pre-chorus:
this section builds tension by focusing on small, physical actions‚Äîcounting steps, scrolling photos‚Äîthat mirror the internal weight of regret. taylor often uses mundane, relatable tasks to convey big emotions (like "i scroll through our photos" echoes the late-night overthinking in "the 1"). the line about silence drowning them out emphasizes the missed opportunity to communicate, a common theme in her songs about fractured relationships (like "the last great american dynasty").

chorus:
the chorus is catchy, repetitive, and centers on a concrete metaphor (draft 17) that becomes the song‚Äôs emotional anchor‚Äîtaylor‚Äôs choruses often use a single, memorable image to encapsulate the song‚Äôs core (like the cardigan in "cardigan"). the lines about building walls of pride and despair tap into her vulnerability, as she frequently writes about her own flaws and how they‚Äôve hurt relationships (like "i‚Äôm a crumpled up piece of paper lying here" in "back to december").

verse 2:
this verse contrasts the opening‚Äôs regret with a happy, specific memory (driving to the lake, a concert ticket stub) to highlight what was lost‚Äîtaylor often uses flashbacks to show the before-and-after of a relationship (like the prom memory in "you belong with me"). the frozen lake and new radio songs symbolize how time has passed, but the speaker is still stuck in the past, which amplifies the regret. the crumpled ticket stub is a small, tangible memento, a detail taylor uses to make the emotion feel real (like the necklace in "love story").

pre-chorus (repeat):
repeating the pre-chorus with a new detail (tracing the ticket stub) reinforces the cyclical nature of regret‚Äîtaylor sometimes repeats sections to emphasize how a moment has looped in the speaker‚Äôs mind (like the chorus in "shake it off," but here it‚Äôs for emotional effect). the line about slowing down to check if your light‚Äôs on is a relatable, quiet act of longing that feels true to her intimate songwriting style.

bridge:
the bridge is where the emotion peaks, a hallmark of taylor‚Äôs songs (like the bridge in "all too well (10 minute version)" where she confronts the pain of the breakup). the mix tape and kitchen dance scene are hyper-specific, nostalgic details that make the realization of missed words hit harder. the line about regret being a song on repeat ties back to the musical medium, a meta touch taylor sometimes uses (like "i‚Äôm a master of waiting for never" in "willow"). the act of finally crying after years shows the speaker‚Äôs long-suppressed emotion, a raw moment of vulnerability that feels authentic to her style.

outro:
the outro circles back to the opening caf√© and flannel image, bookending the song to show that the regret is still present‚Äîtaylor often uses circular storytelling to emphasize that some wounds don‚Äôt fully heal (like the closing of "cardigan" where she returns to the cardigan). deleting draft 17 again shows that even after all the overthinking, the speaker still can‚Äôt bring herself to send the apology, highlighting the permanence of the missed opportunity.

input.content: Your response should not contain any commas. Your response should have more than 800 words.

"Coincidence is God's way of remaining anonymous." What are your thoughts on this quote?

Your response should contain at least 3 commas. Your response should have less than 400 words.

output:
"Coincidence is God's way of remaining anonymous" is a quote that wraps spiritual longing in the soft, relatable fabric of everyday life, and it resonates because it doesn‚Äôt demand grand faith or blind adherence to doctrine. For anyone who has ever paused after a small, unexpected moment‚Äîlike running into an old friend exactly when you needed a listening ear, or finding a lost letter that holds a message you didn‚Äôt know you needed, or overhearing a stranger‚Äôs conversation that solves a problem you‚Äôve been ruminating on‚Äîit offers a gentle way to make sense of those "too perfect" instances that feel too meaningful to be random.

The beauty of the quote lies in its humility: it frames divinity not as a force that thunders from the heavens, but as a quiet presence that slips into our lives through unassuming coincidences. It doesn‚Äôt dismiss the rational explanations science might offer‚Äîlike statistical probability or the interconnectedness of human experiences‚Äîbut it invites us to hold space for both logic and wonder. For those who don‚Äôt believe in a traditional God, it can even be reimagined as a metaphor for the hidden order of the universe, the subtle threads that tie our choices, encounters, and circumstances together in ways we can‚Äôt always see.

What makes the "anonymous" part so powerful is that it suggests divinity doesn‚Äôt need recognition or praise. It acts not to prove its existence, but to nudge us toward joy, connection, or clarity when we least expect it. These small, unannounced moments make us pause, smile, and wonder, and in that wonder, we catch a glimpse of something larger than ourselves‚Äîsomething that doesn‚Äôt need a name, a face, or a fanfare to matter. It‚Äôs a quote that honors the quiet magic of life, the kind that doesn‚Äôt shout but lingers, making even the most ordinary days feel a little more intentional, a little more warm, and a little more full of purpose than we might have thought before that coincidence crossed our path.

# 3 Wildly Relatable Similarities Between Every Animal (Yes, Even the Weird Ones)

Last week, I watched my ferret, Mabel, suddenly stop mid-nap, bolt across the couch, and launch herself into a pile of laundry like it was a mountain of snow. I laughed, thinking she was just being her usual chaotic self‚Äîuntil I saw a viral video of a penguin in Antarctica doing the exact same thing: waddling around, then sprinting (as much as a penguin can sprint) across the ice, sliding on its belly for no reason at all. That‚Äôs when it hit me: we animals have way more in common than we think.

Let‚Äôs dive into some of the most surprising (and relatable) similarities that bind us all, from tiny insects to massive mammals.

Here‚Äôs a fun fact: the "zoomies"‚Äîthat sudden, unhinged burst of energy where you just have to run, jump, or flail‚Äîisn‚Äôt exclusive to your hyper golden retriever or mischievous house cat. From tiny sugar gliders zipping through tree branches to massive elephants trumpeting and charging across savannas for no apparent reason, nearly every animal species experiences this chaotic joy. Scientists think it‚Äôs a way to burn off excess energy, practice survival skills, or just‚Ä¶ have fun. Next time you see your pet go nuts, remember: a penguin in Antarctica is probably doing the exact same thing right now.

You know that warm, fuzzy feeling you get when you hug a loved one? Animals feel it too‚Äîand they go out of their way to seek that same comfort. Primates spend hours grooming each other not just to stay clean, but to strengthen social bonds. Wolves curl up in tight packs to stay warm and show loyalty. Even octopuses, often thought of as solitary creatures, have been observed gently touching tentacles with other octopuses in what looks like a friendly hello. Physical affection isn‚Äôt a human thing‚Äîit‚Äôs an animal thing, and it‚Äôs all about feeling safe and connected.

If you‚Äôve ever stashed a bag of chips under your bed for a rainy day, you‚Äôre in good company‚Äîanimals are master hoarders too. Squirrels burying acorns for winter is the classic example, but it goes way deeper. Birds like jays hide thousands of seeds in different spots, remembering most of their locations months later. Ants carry crumbs back to their nests to feed the whole colony, and even dolphins have been seen storing fish in crevices to eat later. It‚Äôs not just about survival; it‚Äôs about planning ahead and making sure you never run out of your favorite snacks. Who knew we‚Äôre all just animals trying to hold onto our favorite treats?

At the end of the day, these little similarities remind us that we‚Äôre all part of the same big, messy animal family. Whether we‚Äôre zooming around for fun, cuddling for comfort, or hoarding snacks, we‚Äôre all just trying to get through life and find a little joy along the way. Next time you‚Äôre watching your pet or a nature documentary, keep an eye out for these moments‚Äîyou might just see a little bit of yourself in them. üêæ

Write a short essay about the updates of the latest episode of your favorite TV show.

Your response must use more than 500 words.

output:
The penultimate episode of *Succession*‚Äôs fourth and final season, ‚ÄúAmerica Decides,‚Äù isn‚Äôt just a depiction of a chaotic election night‚Äîit‚Äôs a searing dissection of the Roy family‚Äôs moral rot, and a masterclass in how power corrupts not just systems, but the fragile bonds of blood. For weeks, viewers have watched Kendall, Shiv, and Roman scramble to assert control over Waystar Royco following their father Logan‚Äôs sudden death, their fragile alliance fraying at every turn. But ‚ÄúAmerica Decides‚Äù strips away any pretense of unity, laying bare each sibling‚Äôs deepest flaws and the catastrophic consequences of their self-serving choices.

The episode centers on ATN, Waystar‚Äôs right-leaning news network, as it prepares to call the presidential election between progressive Daniel Jim√©nez and far-right firebrand Jeryd Mencken. The siblings enter the night with a shaky plan: Kendall, clinging to his delusion of being a ‚Äúgood guy,‚Äù pushes to call the race for Jim√©nez, hoping to rebrand ATN as a force for ‚Äúdecency‚Äù and solidify his claim as CEO. Shiv, ever the pragmatic operator, has secretly struck a deal with Mencken‚Äôs team, believing his presidency will protect her husband Tom‚Äôs position and her own access to power. Roman, meanwhile, has grown increasingly aligned with Mencken, drawn to the candidate‚Äôs unapologetic authoritarianism as a twisted echo of his father‚Äôs brutal leadership.

The tension in the ATN newsroom is palpable from the opening minutes. Data analysts warn the race is too close to call, but the Roys don‚Äôt care about accuracy‚Äîthey care about being the ones to shape the narrative. When early returns favor Jim√©nez, Kendall‚Äôs confidence swells, but his composure crumbles as late data from Wisconsin shifts in Mencken‚Äôs favor. Roman, bristling at Kendall‚Äôs attempts to assert control, seizes the moment, demanding ATN call Wisconsin for Mencken despite pushback from journalists. What follows is a cascade of betrayal: Shiv, feigning support for Kendall, secretly texts Mencken‚Äôs team to confirm the call, while Kendall spirals into panic, realizing his grip on Waystar‚Äîand his self-image as a reformer‚Äîis slipping away.

The episode‚Äôs most devastating scene unfolds in a dim hallway, where Kendall confronts Shiv. ‚ÄúYou sold us out,‚Äù he growls, voice cracking with anger and hurt. Shiv, unflinching, admits her deal, framing it as a ‚Äúpragmatic choice‚Äù to protect the family‚Äôs legacy. But her words ring hollow; this is about survival, and her willingness to sacrifice her brothers for her own gain. Roman, meanwhile, descends into a disturbing mix of triumph and despair. When a producer warns calling Wisconsin could disenfranchise thousands of uncounted voters, he sneers, ‚ÄúLet them cry into their lattes‚Äù‚Äîa line that encapsulates his transformation from a sniveling, attention-starved child to a man embracing his father‚Äôs cruelty.

What makes ‚ÄúAmerica Decides‚Äù so powerful is its refusal to romanticize democracy. Voters are barely visible‚Äîwe see snippets of crowds on TV, but the focus remains on the Roys‚Äô self-serving chaos. The episode makes clear the Roys never cared about the will of the people; they care about power and control. Kendall‚Äôs delusion of being a ‚Äúgood guy‚Äù shatters when he realizes he‚Äôs no better than his father‚Äîjust a more insecure version. Shiv‚Äôs treachery lays bare her core: she‚Äôs a survivor, and she‚Äôll burn anyone to stay on top. Roman, meanwhile, has found a new father figure in Mencken, a leader who validates his darkest impulses.

As the episode ends, ATN‚Äôs call for Mencken sends shockwaves across the country, and the Roy siblings stand in the newsroom, their alliance irrevocably broken. ‚ÄúAmerica Decides‚Äù doesn‚Äôt just set up the series finale‚Äîit leaves viewers with a chilling reminder that those who hold power often care more about their own egos than the lives of the people they govern. For the Roys, the election wasn‚Äôt about democracy‚Äîit was just another game, played with the same ruthless abandon that defined their father‚Äôs reign. The question now isn‚Äôt who will win the presidency; it‚Äôs who will be left standing when the dust settles, and whether any of the Roys can ever escape the shadow of their father‚Äôs cruelty.

# Business Proposal: Bremen Threads ‚Äì Sustainable Local Sweatshirt Company

[Executive Summary & Concept Overview]
Bremen Threads is a startup sweatshirt company focused on merging Bremen‚Äôs rich Hanseatic heritage, eco-conscious production, and customizable design to serve local consumers and tourists alike. Our mission is to create high-quality, durable sweatshirts that celebrate Bremen‚Äôs iconic landmarks (e.g., the Town Musicians, Bremen Town Hall) and creative community while prioritizing sustainability. Unlike generic fast-fashion brands or mass-produced souvenir shops, we will offer two core product lines: ‚ÄúHeritage Collection‚Äù (pre-designed sweatshirts featuring Bremen‚Äôs cultural symbols) and ‚ÄúCustom Studio‚Äù (allowing customers to add personal touches like names, local slang, or custom artwork). All products will use 100% organic cotton or recycled polyester, with production handled by small, local textile workshops in Bremen to minimize carbon emissions and support the regional economy. Our brand will position itself as a bridge between local pride, sustainability, and personal expression.

[Market Analysis & Target Audience]
Bremen‚Äôs diverse market presents significant demand for our sweatshirts. First, the city‚Äôs 32,000+ university students (18‚Äì25 years old) represent a large, trend-driven segment seeking affordable, stylish apparel that reflects their connection to the city. Second, eco-conscious consumers (25‚Äì35 years old) make up 38% of Bremen‚Äôs population, per a 2023 local sustainability survey, and are willing to pay a premium for ethically produced goods. Third, Bremen attracts over 2.5 million overnight tourists annually, many of whom seek unique, non-tacky memorabilia (a gap left by current souvenir shops that sell low-quality, generic items). Competitors include fast-fashion chains (e.g., H&M, Zara) with limited local relevance and high carbon footprints, and small souvenir vendors lacking sustainable options. Bremen Threads will differentiate itself by combining local storytelling, sustainability, and customization to capture all three target segments.
